CC   -!- FUNCTION: After binding acetylcholine, the AChR responds by an
CC       extensive change in conformation that affects all subunits and
CC       leads to opening of an ion-conducting channel across the plasma
CC       membrane permeable to sodium ions. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22361591}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Neuronal AChR is composed of two different types of
CC       subunits: alpha and beta. Alpha-4 subunit can be combined to beta-
CC       2 or beta-4 to give rise to functional receptors, complexes with
CC       beta-2 may be heteropentamers (PubMed:22361591). Interacts with
CC       RIC3; which is required for proper folding and assembly
CC       (PubMed:16120769). Interacts with LYPD6 (PubMed:27344019). The
CC       heteropentamer alpha-4-beta-2 interacts with alpha-conotoxins
CC       PnIA, GID and MII (By similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P09483,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16120769, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22361591,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27344019}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Lipid-anchor
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P43681-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=P43681-2; Sequence=VSP_054275, VSP_054276;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- DISEASE: Epilepsy, nocturnal frontal lobe, 1 (ENFL1) [MIM:600513]:
CC       An autosomal dominant focal epilepsy characterized by nocturnal
CC       seizures with hyperkinetic automatisms and poorly organized
CC       stereotyped movements. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10563623,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14623738, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7550350}. Note=The
CC       disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in
CC       this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily. Alpha-
CC       4/CHRNA4 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: After binding acetylcholine, the AChR responds by an
CC       extensive change in conformation that affects all subunits and
CC       leads to opening of an ion-conducting channel across the plasma
CC       membrane. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms a homooligomeric channel blocked by alpha-
CC       bungarotoxin. The structure is probably pentameric (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC       Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: This is one of the several different receptors for 5-
CC       hydroxytryptamine (serotonin), a biogenic hormone that functions
CC       as a neurotransmitter, a hormone, and a mitogen. This receptor is
CC       a ligand-gated ion channel, which when activated causes fast,
CC       depolarizing responses in neurons. It is a cation-specific, but
CC       otherwise relatively nonselective, ion channel.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12867984, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9950429}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms pentahomomeric complex as well as pentaheteromeric
CC       complex with HTR3B or HTR3C or HTR3D or HTR3E; homomeric complex
CC       is functional but exhibits low conductance with modified voltage
CC       dependence, and decreased agonist and antagonist affinity.
CC       Interacts with RIC3. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10521471,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15809299, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17392525,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9950429}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q8WXA8:HTR3C; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-9008743, EBI-9008753;
CC       Q70Z44:HTR3D; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-9008743, EBI-9008717;
CC       A5X5Y0-1:HTR3E; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-9008743, EBI-11174612;
CC       A5X5Y0-3:HTR3E; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-9008743, EBI-11163690;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=5;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=5-HT3R-AS;
CC         IsoId=P46098-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=5-HT3R-AL;
CC         IsoId=P46098-2; Sequence=VSP_000078;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=P46098-3; Sequence=VSP_042214;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=P46098-4; Sequence=VSP_043484;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=5;
CC         IsoId=P46098-5; Sequence=VSP_043484, VSP_000078;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available. Ref.7 (CD014118)
CC         sequence is in conflict in position: 342:C->W. {ECO:0000305};
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in cerebral cortex, amygdala,
CC       hippocampus, and testis. Detected in monocytes of the spleen and
CC       tonsil, in small and large intestine, uterus, prostate, ovary and
CC       placenta. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10521471}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The HA-stretch region of HTR3A seems to be
CC       responsible for the low conductance of HTR3A homomers compared to
CC       that of HTR3A/HTR3B heteromers.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. 5-hydroxytryptamine receptor (TC 1.A.9.2) subfamily. HTR3A
CC       sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=7523951; DOI=10.1038/371516a0;
RA   Valera S., Hussy N., Evans R.J., Adami N., North R.A., Surprenant A.,
RA   Buell G.N.;
RT   "A new class of ligand-gated ion channel defined by P2x receptor for

RN   [3]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA] OF 189-399.
RC   STRAIN=Sprague-Dawley; TISSUE=Thymus;
RX   PubMed=2072913; DOI=10.1128/MCB.11.8.4177;
RA   Owens G.P., Hahn W.E., Cohen J.J.;
RT   "Identification of mRNAs associated with programmed cell death in
RT   immature thymocytes.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Biol. 11:4177-4188(1991).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ligand-gated ion channel with relatively high calcium
CC       permeability. Binding to ATP mediates synaptic transmission
CC       between neurons and from neurons to smooth muscle. Seems to be
CC       linked to apoptosis, by increasing the intracellular concentration
CC       of calcium in the presence of ATP, leading to programmed cell
CC       death.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homo- or heteropolymers.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: High levels in vas deferens and urinary
CC       bladder. Lower extent in spinal cord, coeliac ganglion, lung and
CC       spleen (probably in the smooth muscle part of both organs).
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed during apoptosis in thymocytes.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By irradiation and dexamethasone (in thymocytes).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the P2X receptor family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.

RN   [9]
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=22592841; DOI=10.1002/cne.23139;
RA   Weltzien F., Puller C., O'Sullivan G.A., Paarmann I., Betz H.;
RT   "Distribution of the glycine receptor beta-subunit in the mouse CNS as
RT   revealed by a novel monoclonal antibody.";
RL   J. Comp. Neurol. 520:3962-3981(2012).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glycine receptors are ligand-gated chloride channels.
CC       GLRB does not form ligand-gated ion channels by itself, but is
CC       part of heteromeric ligand-gated chloride channels. Channel
CC       opening is triggered by extracellular glycine (PubMed:12809985).
CC       Heteropentameric channels composed of GLRB and GLRA1 are activated
CC       by lower glycine levels than homopentameric GLRA1. Plays an
CC       important role in the down-regulation of neuronal excitability.
CC       Contributes to the generation of inhibitory postsynaptic currents
CC       (PubMed:12809985, PubMed:16672662). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P48167,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12809985, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16672662}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heteropentamer composed of GLRB and GLRA1. Heteropentamer
CC       composed of GLRB and GLRA2. Heteropentamer composed of GLRB and
CC       GLRA3. Heteropentamer composed of two GLRA1 and three GLRB
CC       subunits. Heteropentamer composed of three GLRA1 and two GLRB
CC       subunits. Interacts with GPHN. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P48167}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q03555:Gphn (xeno); NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-7069198, EBI-349317;
CC       Q8BUV3:Gphn; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-7069198, EBI-771218;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22592841}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P48167}. Cell junction, synapse
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19723286, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22592841}. Cell
CC       projection, dendrite {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19723286}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12809985}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P23415}. Cytoplasm
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P48167}. Note=Retained in the cytoplasm
CC       upon heterologous expression by itself. Coexpression with GPHN
CC       promotes expression at the cell membrane. Coexpression with GLRA1,
CC       GLRA2 or GLRA3 promotes expression at the cell membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P20781}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in spinal cord, brain and brain stem,
CC       especially in the periolivary region, spinal nuclei, trigeminal
CC       nucleus, medulla oblongata, pons and midbrain. Detected in the
CC       inner plexiform layer of the retina (at protein level)
CC       (PubMed:22592841). High levels of expression in cortex,
CC       hippocampus, thalamus and cerebellum (PubMed:7920630). Detected in
CC       spinal cord (PubMed:7946325). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22592841,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7920630, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7946325}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Note=Defects in Glrb cause the spastic condition which is
CC       characterized by muscle rigidity, tremors, myoclonic jerks,
CC       pronounced startle reaction, abnormal gait and impaired righting
CC       ability (PubMed:7920630). Neurons from the ventral horn of the
CC       spinal cord display reduced inhibitory postsynaptic currents
CC       (PubMed:12809985). Likewise, hypoglossal neurons display a
CC       dramatic reduction in the frequency and amplitude of postsynaptic
CC       inhibitory currents (PubMed:16672662).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12809985, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16672662,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7920630}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Glycine receptor (TC 1.A.9.3) subfamily. GLRB sub-
CC       subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: The alpha4 beta2 gamma 2L receptor is not repressed by
CC       diazepam. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8719416}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor (TC 1.A.9.5) subfamily.
CC       GABRA4 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Protein Spotlight; Note=Forbidden fruit - Issue
CC       56 of March 2005;
CC       URL="https://web.expasy.org/spotlight/back_issues/056";

RP   DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=17128266; DOI=10.1038/nn1810;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: After binding acetylcholine, the AChR responds by an
CC       extensive change in conformation that affects all subunits and
CC       leads to opening of an ion-conducting channel across the plasma
CC       membrane (By similarity). A subunit of the levamisole-insensitive
CC       nicotinic receptor. {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15917232,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8627624}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15944127}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15944127}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15944127}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15944127}. Note=The cam-1 protein is required
CC       for correct localization.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=a;
CC         IsoId=P48180-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=b;
CC         IsoId=P48180-2; Sequence=VSP_036472;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the body wall muscle.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15917232}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Uncoordinated movement and reduced body wall
CC       muscle currents. These phenotypes are probably related.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15944127, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17128266}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Non-alpha subunit of nicotinic acetylcholine receptor
CC       (nAChR). Involved in nAChR sensitivity to nicotine and levasimole.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990870}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with lev-1 (PubMed:15990870). Component of
CC       nicotinic acetylcholine receptor composed of 2 non-alpha subunits
CC       lev-1 and unc-29, and 3 alpha subunits unc-38, unc-63 and lev-8
CC       (PubMed:15990870). Interacts with oig-4 (PubMed:21252855).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990870, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21252855}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990870}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990870}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}. Note=Co-localizes with unc-38 and lev-1 at nerve
CC       cord synapses. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990870}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: RNAi-mediated knockdown causes a resistance
CC       to nicotine-mediated paralysis and small impairment in mobility.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990870}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, INTERACTION WITH NICOTINIC ACETYLCHOLINE RECEPTOR, TISSUE
RP   SPECIFICITY, DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE, DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE, AND
RP   MUTAGENESIS OF VAL-309.
RX   PubMed=20027209; DOI=10.1371/journal.pbio.1000265;
RA   Jospin M., Qi Y.B., Stawicki T.M., Boulin T., Schuske K.R.,
RA   Horvitz H.R., Bessereau J.L., Jorgensen E.M., Jin Y.;

RT   excitation and inhibition in Caenorhabditis elegans.";
RL   PLoS Biol. 7:E1000265-E1000265(2009).
RN   [4]
RP   FUNCTION, AND MUTAGENESIS OF VAL-309.
RX   PubMed=23658528; DOI=10.1371/journal.pgen.1003472;
RA   Stawicki T.M., Takayanagi-Kiya S., Zhou K., Jin Y.;
RT   "Neuropeptides function in a homeostatic manner to modulate
RT   excitation-inhibition imbalance in C. elegans.";
RL   PLoS Genet. 9:E1003472-E1003472(2013).
RN   [5]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=27782882; DOI=10.7554/eLife.21734;
RA   Takayanagi-Kiya S., Zhou K., Jin Y.;
RT   "Release-dependent feedback inhibition by a presynaptically localized
RT   ligand-gated anion channel.";
RL   Elife 5:21734-21749(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Non-alpha subunit of nicotinic acetylcholine receptor
CC       (nAChR) (PubMed:8581398, PubMed:20027209). Acts in cholinergic
CC       motoneurons to regulate presynaptic neurotransmitter release,
CC       thereby ensuring normal level of excitation of cholinergic
CC       motoneurons during locomotion (PubMed:20027209, PubMed:23658528,
CC       PubMed:27782882). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20027209,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23658528, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8581398}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of nicotinic acetylcholine receptor. In
CC       cholinergic motoneurons, composed of 2 non-alpha subunits acr-2
CC       and acr-3, and 3 alpha subunits unc-38, unc-63 and acr-12.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20027209, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8581398}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q23022}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q23022}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Specifically expressed in cholinergic ventral
CC       cord motoneurons of the VA, VB, DA and DB classes but not AS and
CC       VC classes. Expressed in PVQ and DVC neurons in the tail.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20027209}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed from L1 larval stage through
CC       adults. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20027209}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Locomotion is slower. Moderately resistant
CC       to paralysis induced by acetylcholine esterase inhibitor aldicarb
CC       but sensitivity to acetylcholine agonist levamisole is normal.
CC       Reduced both cholinergic and GABAergic motoneuron activities
CC       characterized by a reduction in miniature postsynaptic currents in
CC       muscles. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20027209}.

RX   PubMed=9203638;
RA   Gerzanich V., Kuryatov A., Anand R., Lindstrom J.;
RT   "'Orphan' alpha6 nicotinic AChR subunit can form a functional
RT   heteromeric acetylcholine receptor.";
RL   Mol. Pharmacol. 51:320-327(1997).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: After binding acetylcholine, the AChR responds by an
CC       extensive change in conformation that affects all subunits and
CC       leads to opening of an ion-conducting channel across the plasma
CC       membrane.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Neuronal AChR seems to be composed of two different type
CC       of subunits: alpha and non-alpha (also called beta). A functional
CC       receptor seems to consist of two alpha-chains and three non-alpha
CC       chains.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily. Alpha-
CC       6/CHRNA6 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   DISULFIDE BOND.
RX   PubMed=12921863; DOI=10.1016/S0014-2999(03)02038-7;
RA   Nakazawa K., Ojima H., Ishii-Nozawa R., Takeuchi K., Ohno Y.;
RT   "Intracellular disulfide bond that affects ATP responsiveness of
RT   P2X(2) receptor/channel.";
RL   Eur. J. Pharmacol. 474:205-208(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ion channel gated by extracellular ATP involved in a
CC       variety of cellular responses, such as excitatory postsynaptic
CC       responses in sensory neurons, neuromuscular junctions (NMJ)
CC       formation, hearing, perception of taste and peristalsis. In the
CC       inner ear, regulates sound transduction and auditory
CC       neurotransmission, outer hair cell electromotility, inner ear gap
CC       junctions, and K(+) recycling. Mediates synaptic transmission
CC       between neurons and from neurons to smooth muscle (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotrimer and heterotrimer; functional P2XRs are
CC       organized as homomeric and heteromeric trimers. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P51577:P2rx4; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-9511543, EBI-9511617;
CC       P51579:P2rx6; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-9511543, EBI-9511515;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC         Comment=Additional isoforms seem to exist.;
CC       Name=P2RX2-1;
CC         IsoId=P49653-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=P2RX2-2;
CC         IsoId=P49653-2; Sequence=VSP_004501, VSP_004502;
CC       Name=P2RX2-3;
CC         IsoId=P49653-3; Sequence=VSP_004500;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: High levels in pituitary and vas deferens.
CC       Lower extent in spinal cord, bladder, brain, adrenal, testis,
CC       sensory epithelia from the inner ear.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the P2X receptor family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ligand-gated ion channel with relatively high calcium
CC       permeability. Binding to ATP mediates synaptic transmission
CC       between neurons and from neurons to smooth muscle. Seems to be
CC       linked to apoptosis, by increasing the intracellular concentration
CC       of calcium in the presence of ATP, leading to programmed cell
CC       death (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homo- or heteropolymers. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the P2X receptor family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Receptor for ATP that acts as a ligand-gated ion
CC       channel. This receptor is insensitive to the antagonists PPADS and
CC       suramin.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Functional P2XRs are organized as homomeric and
CC       heteromeric trimers. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-9511617, EBI-9511617;
CC       P49653:P2rx2; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-9511617, EBI-9511543;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Widespread distribution in the brain. Also
CC       expressed in epithelial cells.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the P2X receptor family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   MUTAGENESIS OF ILE-314.
RX   PubMed=17891142; DOI=10.1038/nn1981;
RA   Van Buskirk C., Sternberg P.W.;
RT   "Epidermal growth factor signaling induces behavioral quiescence in
RT   Caenorhabditis elegans.";
RL   Nat. Neurosci. 10:1300-1307(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Subunit of the non-synaptic neuronal acetylcholine
CC       receptor, which may play a role in chemotaxis towards choline.
CC       After binding choline or acetylcholine, the AChR responds by an
CC       extensive change in conformation that affects all subunits and
CC       leads to opening of an ion-conducting channel across the plasma
CC       membrane (PubMed:9860996, PubMed:11273652).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11273652, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9860996}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The functional receptor is a heteromer of deg-3 and des-
CC       2. Interacts with ric-3; which is required for proper receptor
CC       folding. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11867529,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15932871, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9860996}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11273652}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11273652}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11273652}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11273652}. Note=Enriched in the sensory
CC       endings of sensory neurons.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: This locus is redundant or nonessential as
CC       suppression of deg-3 function results in wild-type revertants.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RL   Submitted (APR-2017) to the PDB data bank.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of NMDA receptor complexes that function as
CC       heterotetrameric, ligand-gated ion channels with high calcium
CC       permeability and voltage-dependent sensitivity to magnesium.
CC       Channel activation requires binding of the neurotransmitter
CC       glutamate to the epsilon subunit, glycine binding to the zeta
CC       subunit, plus membrane depolarization to eliminate channel
CC       inhibition by Mg(2+). Sensitivity to glutamate and channel
CC       kinetics depend on the subunit composition; channels containing
CC       GRIN1 and GRIN2A have higher sensitivity to glutamate and faster
CC       kinetics than channels formed by GRIN1 and GRIN2B
CC       (PubMed:28384476). Contributes to the slow phase of excitatory
CC       postsynaptic current, long-term synaptic potentiation, and
CC       learning (By similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P35436,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1350383, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16281028,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23625947, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24462099,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27618671, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27916457,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28384476, ECO:0000269|PubMed:28468946,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28760974, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8428958}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Channel activity is inhibited by nM
CC       concentrations of Zn(2+). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27916457}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer. Forms heterotetrameric channels composed
CC       of two zeta subunits (GRIN1), and two epsilon subunits (GRIN2A,
CC       GRIN2B, GRIN2C or GRIN2D) (in vitro) (PubMed:1350383,
CC       PubMed:8428958, PubMed:28384476, PubMed:16281028, PubMed:23625947,
CC       PubMed:24462099, PubMed:27618671, PubMed:27916457,
CC       PubMed:28468946, PubMed:28760974, Ref.24). Can also form
CC       heterotetrameric channels that contain at least one zeta subunit
CC       (GRIN1), at least one epsilon subunit, plus GRIN3A or GRIN3B
CC       (PubMed:11160393, PubMed:11588171, PubMed:12391275,
CC       PubMed:11929923). In vivo, the subunit composition may depend on
CC       the expression levels of the different subunits (Probable). Found
CC       in a complex with GRIN1, GRIN3A and PPP2CB (PubMed:11588171).
CC       Found in a complex with GRIN1 and GRIN3B (PubMed:14602821).
CC       Interacts with AIP1 (PubMed:9694864). Interacts with HIP1 and
CC       NETO1. Interacts with SNX27 (via PDZ domain); the interaction is
CC       required for recycling to the plasma membrane when endocytosed and
CC       prevent degradation in lysosomes (By similarity). Interacts with
CC       PDZ domains of PATJ and DLG4 (PubMed:7569905, PubMed:9647694).
CC       Interacts with LRFN2 (PubMed:16495444).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P35436, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11160393,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11588171, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11929923,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12391275, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1350383,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14602821, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16281028,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16495444, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23625947,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24462099, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27618671,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27916457, ECO:0000269|PubMed:28384476,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28468946, ECO:0000269|PubMed:28760974,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7569905, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8428958,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9647694, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9694864,
CC       ECO:0000269|Ref.24, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P31016:Dlg4; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-630970, EBI-375655;
CC       Q8R4I7:Neto1 (xeno); NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-630970, EBI-2314926;
CC       P05480:Src (xeno); NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-630970, EBI-298680;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11160393,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1350383, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14602821,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16281028, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23625947,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24462099, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27618671,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27916457, ECO:0000269|PubMed:28384476,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:28468946, ECO:0000269|PubMed:28760974,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8428958}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305}. Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9509416}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in brain cortex, olfactory bulb,
CC       hippocampus, striatum, thalamus, superior colliculus, inferior
CC       colliculus, midbrain and cerebellum (at protein level)
CC       (PubMed:9509416). Detected in brain cortex, hypothalamus and
CC       cerebellum. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1350383,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9509416}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Contains an N-terminal domain, a ligand-binding domain and
CC       a transmembrane domain. Agonist binding to the extracellular
CC       ligand-binding domains triggers channel gating.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:16281028}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: A hydrophobic region that gives rise to the prediction of
CC       a transmembrane span does not cross the membrane, but is part of a
CC       discontinuously helical region that dips into the membrane and is
CC       probably part of the pore and of the selectivity filter.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:B7ZSK1}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. NR2A/GRIN2A subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [17] {ECO:0000244|PDB:5TPZ}
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.10 ANGSTROMS) OF 32-393 IN COMPLEX WITH
RP   GRIN1, FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, SUBUNIT, GLYCOSYLATION AT
RP   ASN-341, AND DISULFIDE BONDS.
RX   PubMed=27916457; DOI=10.1016/j.neuron.2016.11.006;
RA   Romero-Hernandez A., Simorowski N., Karakas E., Furukawa H.;
RT   "Molecular Basis for Subtype Specificity and High-Affinity Zinc
RT   Inhibition in the GluN1-GluN2A NMDA Receptor Amino-Terminal Domain.";
RL   Neuron 92:1324-1336(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of NMDA receptor complexes that function as
CC       heterotetrameric, ligand-gated ion channels with high calcium
CC       permeability and voltage-dependent sensitivity to magnesium.
CC       Channel activation requires binding of the neurotransmitter
CC       glutamate to the epsilon subunit, glycine binding to the zeta
CC       subunit, plus membrane depolarization to eliminate channel
CC       inhibition by Mg(2+) (PubMed:1350383, PubMed:19910922,
CC       PubMed:21677647, PubMed:24876489, PubMed:27135925,
CC       PubMed:27916457). Sensitivity to glutamate and channel kinetics
CC       depend on the subunit composition (Probable). In concert with
CC       DAPK1 at extrasynaptic sites, acts as a central mediator for
CC       stroke damage. Its phosphorylation at Ser-1303 by DAPK1 enhances
CC       synaptic NMDA receptor channel activity inducing injurious Ca2+
CC       influx through them, resulting in an irreversible neuronal death.
CC       Contributes to neural pattern formation in the developing brain.
CC       Plays a role in long-term depression (LTD) of hippocampus membrane
CC       currents and in synaptic plasticity (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q01097, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1350383,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19910922, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21677647,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24876489, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27135925,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27916457, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Channel activity is inhibited by micromolar
CC       levels of zinc ions (PubMed:19910922). Channel activity is
CC       inhibited by ifenprodil (PubMed:19910922, PubMed:21677647).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19910922, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21677647}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer. Forms heterotetrameric channels composed
CC       of two zeta subunits (GRIN1), and two epsilon subunits (GRIN2A,
CC       GRIN2B, GRIN2C or GRIN2D) (in vitro) (PubMed:1350383,
CC       PubMed:19910922, PubMed:21677647, PubMed:24876489,
CC       PubMed:27135925, PubMed:27916457). Can also form heterotetrameric
CC       channels that contain at least one zeta subunit (GRIN1), at least
CC       one epsilon subunit, plus GRIN3A or GRIN3B. In vivo, the subunit
CC       composition may depend on the expression levels of the different
CC       subunits. Found in a complex with GRIN1, GRIN3A and PPP2CB. Found
CC       in a complex with GRIN1 and GRIN3B. Interacts with MAGI3.
CC       Interacts with HIP1 and NETO1. Interacts with PDZ domains of PATJ
CC       and DLG4. Interacts with DAPK1 (By similarity). Found in a complex
CC       with GRIN1 and PRR7 (PubMed:27458189). Interacts with PRR7
CC       (PubMed:27458189). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q01097,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q13224, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1350383,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19910922, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21677647,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24876489, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27135925,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27458189, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27916457}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P11275:Camk2a; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-396905, EBI-2640645;
CC       P11798:Camk2a (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-396905, EBI-400384;
CC       Q62936:Dlg3; NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-396905, EBI-349596;
CC       P31016:Dlg4; NbExp=8; IntAct=EBI-396905, EBI-375655;
CC       P35439:Grin1; NbExp=12; IntAct=EBI-396905, EBI-877897;
CC       P35439-7:Grin1; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-396905, EBI-15932497;
CC       Q91977:grin1 (xeno); NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-396905, EBI-15932423;
CC       Q460M5:Lrfn2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-396905, EBI-877185;
CC       Q8R4I7:Neto1 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-396905, EBI-2314926;
CC       Q63ZW7:Patj (xeno); NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-396905, EBI-8366894;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1350383,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19910922, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21677647,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24876489, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27135925,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27916457}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24876489, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27135925}. Cell
CC       junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7513428, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9509416}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24876489,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27135925}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in adult olfactory bulb, brain
CC       cortex, hippocampus, striatum, thalamus, superior colliculus, with
CC       much lower levels in inferior colliculus, midbrain and cerebellum.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9509416}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: A hydrophobic region that gives rise to the prediction of
CC       a transmembrane span does not cross the membrane, but is part of a
CC       discontinuously helical region that dips into the membrane and is
CC       probably part of the pore and of the selectivity filter.
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:24876489}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated on tyrosine residues (PubMed:7513428).
CC       Phosphorylation at Ser-1303 by DAPK1 enhances synaptic NMDA
CC       receptor channel activity (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q01097, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7513428}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. NR2B/GRIN2B subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

ID   GRIK4_RAT               Reviewed;         956 AA.
AC   Q01812; Q62642;
DT   15-JUL-1998, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.
DT   01-NOV-1996, sequence version 1.
DT   22-NOV-2017, entry version 142.
DE   RecName: Full=Glutamate receptor ionotropic, kainate 4;
DE            Short=GluK4;
DE   AltName: Full=Glutamate receptor KA-1;
DE            Short=KA1;
DE   Flags: Precursor;
GN   Name=Grik4;
OS   Rattus norvegicus (Rat).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Craniata; Vertebrata; Euteleostomi;
OC   Mammalia; Eutheria; Euarchontoglires; Glires; Rodentia; Myomorpha;
OC   Muroidea; Muridae; Murinae; Rattus.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=10116;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA].
RC   TISSUE=Brain;
RX   PubMed=1648176; DOI=10.1038/351742a0;
RA   Werner P., Voigt M., Keinaenen K., Wisden W., Seeburg P.H.;
RT   "Cloning of a putative high-affinity kainate receptor expressed
RT   predominantly in hippocampal CA3 cells.";
RL   Nature 351:742-744(1991).
RN   [2]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA].
RC   STRAIN=Sprague-Dawley; TISSUE=Brain;
RA   Boulter J., Pecht G.;
RL   Submitted (MAY-1994) to the EMBL/GenBank/DDBJ databases.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Receptor for glutamate. L-glutamate acts as an
CC       excitatory neurotransmitter at many synapses in the central
CC       nervous system. The postsynaptic actions of Glu are mediated by a
CC       variety of receptors that are named according to their selective
CC       agonists. This receptor binds kainate > quisqualate > glutamate >>
CC       AMPA.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms a heteromeric channel with GRIK1 or GRIK3.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC       Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Strong expression in hippocampal CA3 pyramidal
CC       cells. Low expression in hippocampal dentate granule cells, in
CC       layers II, V and VI of the cortex, and in cerebellar Purkinje
CC       cells. No expression in the striatum, reticular thalamus,
CC       hypothalamus or amygdaloid complex.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed at embryonic day 15 in brain and
CC       spinal cord. At embryonic day 19 expression accumulates in the
CC       hippocampal formation. Prominent expression in the subicular
CC       cortex at postnatal days P1, P8 and P15 but then markedly reduced
CC       in the adult.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. GRIK4 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA] (ISOFORMS 1 AND 2).
RC   STRAIN=Berkeley; TISSUE=Embryo;
RA   Stapleton M., Brokstein P., Hong L., Agbayani A., Carlson J.W.,
RA   Booth B., Champe M., Chavez C., Dorsett V., Dresnek D., Farfan D.,
RA   Frise E., George R.A., Gonzalez M., Guarin H., Kronmiller B., Li P.W.,
RA   Liao G., Miranda A., Mungall C.J., Nunoo J., Pacleb J.M., Paragas V.,
RA   Park S., Patel S., Phouanenavong S., Wan K.H., Yu C., Lewis S.E.,
RA   Rubin G.M., Celniker S.E.;
RL   Submitted (NOV-2008) to the EMBL/GenBank/DDBJ databases.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Receptor for glutamate. L-glutamate acts as an
CC       excitatory neurotransmitter at many synapses in the central
CC       nervous system. The postsynaptic actions of Glu are mediated by a
CC       variety of receptors that are named according to their selective
CC       agonists (By similarity). Forms ligand-gated ion channels which
CC       are activated by kainate. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:1359540}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homooligomer. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1359540};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1359540}. Cell
CC       junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell membrane {ECO:0000250};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=A;
CC         IsoId=Q03445-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q03445-2; Sequence=VSP_014219;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Central nervous system.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1359540}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: No expression is seen in early embryogenesis,
CC       whereas high expression occurs in late embryos. During larval
CC       development, expression decreases to undetectable levels in late
CC       larvae, resumes at the early pupal stage and gradually increases
CC       in late pupae and early adult flies. High levels of expression
CC       coincide with major stages of neurogenesis.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1359540}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Meisel J.D., Panda O., Mahanti P., Schroeder F.C., Kim D.H.;

RN   [8]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=25009271; DOI=10.1523/JNEUROSCI.0012-14.2014;
RA   Harris G., Shen Y., Ha H., Donato A., Wallis S., Zhang X., Zhang Y.;
RT   "Dissecting the signaling mechanisms underlying recognition and
RT   preference of food odors.";
RL   J. Neurosci. 34:9389-9403(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required for normal thermosensation and chemosensation
CC       sensory behavior (PubMed:8893027). Required, downstream of
CC       receptor-type guanylate cyclase gcy-9, for CO2-mediated responses
CC       in BAG neurons (PubMed:21173231). Required, downstream of
CC       receptor-type guanylate cyclase gcy-14, for alkaline pH-mediated
CC       responses in ASE-left (ASEL) neurons (PubMed:23664973). Involved
CC       in the development of ASJ sensory neuron axon during late larval
CC       stages and in the maintenance of normal axon morphology in the
CC       adult. Regulates dauer formation (PubMed:9486798). In ASI and ASJ
CC       sensory neurons, controls behavioral response to P.aeruginosa by
CC       up-regulating the transcription of daf-7, a member of the TGF-beta
CC       family (PubMed:25303524). In AWB and AWC sensory neurons, mediates
CC       the recognition of food oders which subsequently allows for the
CC       detection of preferred food sources (PubMed:25009271).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21173231, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23664973,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25009271, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25303524,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8893027, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9486798}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed at the sensory endings of
CC       thermosensory, gustatory, and olfactory neurons.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cyclic nucleotide-gated cation channel
CC       (TC 1.A.1.5) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 92:758-762(1995).

RX   PubMed=27375219; DOI=10.1002/humu.23043;
RA   Shen X.M., Okuno T., Milone M., Otsuka K., Takahashi K., Komaki H.,
RA   Giles E., Ohno K., Engel A.G.;

RT   in the channel pore of muscle AChR is optimized for stabilizing
RT   channel gating.";
RL   Hum. Mutat. 37:1051-1059(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: After binding acetylcholine, the AChR responds by an
CC       extensive change in conformation that affects all subunits and
CC       leads to opening of an ion-conducting channel across the plasma
CC       membrane. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27375219}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pentamer of two alpha chains, and one each of the beta,
CC       delta, and gamma (in immature muscle) or epsilon (in mature
CC       muscle) chains. The muscle heteropentamer composed of alpha-1,
CC       beta-1, delta, epsilon subunits interacts with the alpha-conotoxin
CC       ImII (PubMed:15609996). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15609996}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Note=The muscle AChR is the major target antigen in the
CC       autoimmune disease myasthenia gravis. Myasthenia gravis is
CC       characterized by sporadic muscular fatigability and weakness,
CC       occurring chiefly in muscles innervated by cranial nerves, and
CC       characteristically improved by cholinesterase-inhibiting drugs.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Myasthenic syndrome, congenital, 4A, slow-channel (CMS4A)
CC       [MIM:605809]: A form of congenital myasthenic syndrome, a group of
CC       disorders characterized by failure of neuromuscular transmission,
CC       including pre-synaptic, synaptic, and post-synaptic disorders that
CC       are not of autoimmune origin. Clinical features are easy
CC       fatigability and muscle weakness affecting the axial and limb
CC       muscles (with hypotonia in early-onset forms), the ocular muscles
CC       (leading to ptosis and ophthalmoplegia), and the facial and bulbar
CC       musculature (affecting sucking and swallowing, and leading to
CC       dysphonia). The symptoms fluctuate and worsen with physical
CC       effort. CMS4A is a slow-channel myasthenic syndrome. It is caused
CC       by kinetic abnormalities of the AChR, resulting in prolonged AChR
CC       channel opening episodes, prolonged endplate currents, and
CC       depolarization block. This is associated with calcium overload,
CC       which may contribute to subsequent degeneration of the endplate
CC       and postsynaptic membrane. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12141316,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27375219, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7531341,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7538206, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8872460}. Note=The
CC       disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in
CC       this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Myasthenic syndrome, congenital, 4B, fast-channel (CMS4B)
CC       [MIM:616324]: A form of congenital myasthenic syndrome, a group of
CC       disorders characterized by failure of neuromuscular transmission,
CC       including pre-synaptic, synaptic, and post-synaptic disorders that
CC       are not of autoimmune origin. Clinical features are easy
CC       fatigability and muscle weakness affecting the axial and limb
CC       muscles (with hypotonia in early-onset forms), the ocular muscles
CC       (leading to ptosis and ophthalmoplegia), and the facial and bulbar
CC       musculature (affecting sucking and swallowing, and leading to
CC       dysphonia). The symptoms fluctuate and worsen with physical
CC       effort. CMS4B is a fast-channel myasthenic syndrome. It is caused
CC       by kinetic abnormalities of the AChR, resulting in brief opening
CC       and activity of the channel, with a rapid decay in endplate
CC       current, failure to achieve threshold depolarization of the
CC       endplate and consequent failure to fire an action potential.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10962020, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22592360,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8755487}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Myasthenic syndrome, congenital, 4C, associated with
CC       acetylcholine receptor deficiency (CMS4C) [MIM:608931]: A form of
CC       congenital myasthenic syndrome, a group of disorders characterized
CC       by failure of neuromuscular transmission, including pre-synaptic,
CC       synaptic, and post-synaptic disorders that are not of autoimmune
CC       origin. Clinical features are easy fatigability and muscle
CC       weakness affecting the axial and limb muscles (with hypotonia in
CC       early-onset forms), the ocular muscles (leading to ptosis and
CC       ophthalmoplegia), and the facial and bulbar musculature (affecting
CC       sucking and swallowing, and leading to dysphonia). The symptoms
CC       fluctuate and worsen with physical effort. CMS4C is an autosomal
CC       recessive disorder of postsynaptic neuromuscular transmission, due
CC       to deficiency of AChR at the endplate that results in low
CC       amplitude of the miniature endplate potential and current.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9158150}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily.
CC       Epsilon/CHRNE sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: After binding acetylcholine, the AChR responds by an
CC       extensive change in conformation that affects all subunits and
CC       leads to opening of an ion-conducting channel across the plasma
CC       membrane.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Neuronal AChR seems to be composed of two different type
CC       of subunits: alpha and beta.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily. Beta-
CC       3/CHRNB3 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: After binding acetylcholine, the AChR responds by an
CC       extensive change in conformation that affects all subunits and
CC       leads to opening of an ion-conducting channel across the plasma
CC       membrane. The channel is blocked by alpha-bungarotoxin.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homopentamer (By similarity). Interacts with RIC3; which
CC       is required for proper folding and assembly (PubMed:15927954,
CC       PubMed:16120769). Interacts with LYPD6 (By similarity). Interacts
CC       with the alpha-conotoxin RgIA (PubMed:25740413). Interacts with
CC       alpha-conotoxins ImI and ImII (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P36544, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P54131,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15927954, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16120769,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25740413}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P60615:- (xeno); NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-79422, EBI-7516391;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily. Alpha-
CC       7/CHRNA7 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

FT                                alpha-conotoxin RgIA.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25740413}.
FT   MUTAGEN     433    433       L->A: Abolishes dependency on RIC3 for
FT                                functional expression.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15927954}.
FT   MUTAGEN     435    435       K->A: No effect on dependency on RIC3 for
FT                                functional expression.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15927954}.
FT   MUTAGEN     440    440       V->A: Impairs dependency on RIC3 for
FT                                functional expression.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15927954}.

FT                                for functional expression.
FT                                {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15927954}.

FT                                functional expression.

FT                                functional expression.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: After binding acetylcholine, the AChR responds by an
CC       extensive change in conformation that affects all subunits and
CC       leads to opening of an ion-conducting channel across the plasma
CC       membrane. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27375219}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pentamer of two alpha chains, and one each of the beta,
CC       delta, and gamma (in immature muscle) or epsilon (in mature
CC       muscle) chains. The muscle heteropentamer composed of alpha-1,
CC       beta-1, delta, epsilon subunits interacts with the alpha-conotoxin
CC       ImII (PubMed:15609996). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15609996}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q07001-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q07001-2; Sequence=VSP_046423;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- DISEASE: Multiple pterygium syndrome, lethal type (LMPS)
CC       [MIM:253290]: Multiple pterygia are found infrequently in children
CC       with arthrogryposis and in fetuses with fetal akinesia syndrome.
CC       In lethal multiple pterygium syndrome there is intrauterine growth
CC       retardation, multiple pterygia, and flexion contractures causing
CC       severe arthrogryposis and fetal akinesia. Subcutaneous edema can
CC       be severe, causing fetal hydrops with cystic hygroma and lung
CC       hypoplasia. Oligohydramnios and facial anomalies are frequent.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18252226}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Myasthenic syndrome, congenital, 3A, slow-channel (CMS3A)
CC       [MIM:616321]: A form of congenital myasthenic syndrome, a group of
CC       disorders characterized by failure of neuromuscular transmission,
CC       including pre-synaptic, synaptic, and post-synaptic disorders that
CC       are not of autoimmune origin. Clinical features are easy
CC       fatigability and muscle weakness affecting the axial and limb
CC       muscles (with hypotonia in early-onset forms), the ocular muscles
CC       (leading to ptosis and ophthalmoplegia), and the facial and bulbar
CC       musculature (affecting sucking and swallowing, and leading to
CC       dysphonia). The symptoms fluctuate and worsen with physical
CC       effort. CMS3A is a slow-channel myasthenic syndrome. It is caused
CC       by kinetic abnormalities of the AChR, resulting in prolonged AChR
CC       channel opening episodes, prolonged endplate currents, and
CC       depolarization block. This is associated with calcium overload,
CC       which may contribute to subsequent degeneration of the endplate
CC       and postsynaptic membrane. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11782989,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8872460}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Myasthenic syndrome, congenital, 3B, fast-channel (CMS3B)
CC       [MIM:616322]: A form of congenital myasthenic syndrome, a group of
CC       disorders characterized by failure of neuromuscular transmission,
CC       including pre-synaptic, synaptic, and post-synaptic disorders that
CC       are not of autoimmune origin. Clinical features are easy
CC       fatigability and muscle weakness affecting the axial and limb
CC       muscles (with hypotonia in early-onset forms), the ocular muscles
CC       (leading to ptosis and ophthalmoplegia), and the facial and bulbar
CC       musculature (affecting sucking and swallowing, and leading to
CC       dysphonia). The symptoms fluctuate and worsen with physical
CC       effort. CMS3B is a fast-channel myasthenic syndrome. It is caused
CC       by kinetic abnormalities of the AChR, resulting in brief opening
CC       and activity of the channel, with a rapid decay in endplate
CC       current, failure to achieve threshold depolarization of the
CC       endplate and consequent failure to fire an action potential.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11435464, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12499478,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18398509}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Myasthenic syndrome, congenital, 3C, associated with
CC       acetylcholine receptor deficiency (CMS3C) [MIM:616323]: A form of
CC       congenital myasthenic syndrome, a group of disorders characterized
CC       by failure of neuromuscular transmission, including pre-synaptic,
CC       synaptic, and post-synaptic disorders that are not of autoimmune
CC       origin. Clinical features are easy fatigability and muscle
CC       weakness affecting the axial and limb muscles (with hypotonia in
CC       early-onset forms), the ocular muscles (leading to ptosis and
CC       ophthalmoplegia), and the facial and bulbar musculature (affecting
CC       sucking and swallowing, and leading to dysphonia). The symptoms
CC       fluctuate and worsen with physical effort. CMS3C is an autosomal
CC       recessive disorder of postsynaptic neuromuscular transmission, due
CC       to deficiency of AChR at the endplate that results in low
CC       amplitude of the miniature endplate potential and current.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16916845, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18398509}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily. Delta/CHRND
CC       sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND INTERACTION WITH GRD.
RX   PubMed=15148245; DOI=10.1038/sj.bjp.0705818;
RA   Gisselmann G., Plonka J., Pusch H., Hatt H.;
RT   "Drosophila melanogaster GRD and LCCH3 subunits form heteromultimeric
RT   GABA-gated cation channels.";
RL   Br. J. Pharmacol. 142:409-413(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, an inhibitory neurotransmitter, mediates neuronal
CC       inhibition by binding to the GABA receptor and opening an integral
CC       chloride channel. Combines with the ligand-gated ion channel
CC       subunit GRD to form cation-selective GABA-gated ion channels when
CC       coexpressed in Xenopus laevis oocytes.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15148245}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho. Interacts
CC       with Grd (alpha chain). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15148245}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor (TC 1.A.9.5) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE GENOMIC DNA].
RC   STRAIN=Bristol N2;

RG   The C. elegans sequencing consortium;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glycine receptors are ligand-gated chloride channels.
CC       Channel opening is triggered by extracellular glycine. Contributes
CC       to the generation of inhibitory postsynaptic currents.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P48168}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pentamer. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P48167}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P48168}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P48167}. Cell junction, synapse

CC   -!- FUNCTION: L-glutamate acts as an excitatory neurotransmitter at
CC       many synapses in the central nervous system. The postsynaptic
CC       actions of glutamate are mediated by a variety of receptors that
CC       are named according to their selective agonists. Required for
CC       response to mechanical and osmotic stimuli.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12467596}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}. Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=b;
CC         IsoId=Q10914-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=a;
CC         IsoId=Q10914-2; Sequence=VSP_008031;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Command interneurons of the locomotory control
CC       circuit (AIA, AIB, AVA, AVD, AVE, PVC, RIA, RIG and RIR) and motor
CC       neurons (AVG, M1, RMDD and RMDV). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11222641}.

RT   under native conditions.";
RL   Nat. Neurosci. 7:705-710(2004).
RN   [9]
RP   ALTERNATIVE SPLICING (ISOFORM GARP2), AND FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=16407240; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M507488200;
RA   Pentia D.C., Hosier S., Cote R.H.;
RT   "The glutamic acid-rich protein-2 (GARP2) is a high affinity rod
RT   photoreceptor phosphodiesterase (PDE6)-binding protein that modulates
RT   its catalytic properties.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 281:5500-5505(2006).
RN   [10]
RP   CHARACTERIZATION OF THE GARPS PROTEINS.
RX   PubMed=16280326; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M505012200;
RA   Batra-Safferling R., Abarca-Heidemann K., Korschen H.G., Tziatzios C.,
RA   Stoldt M., Budyak I., Willbold D., Schwalbe H., Klein-Seetharaman J.,
RA   Kaupp U.B.;
RT   "Glutamic acid-rich proteins of rod photoreceptors are natively
RT   unfolded.";

RN   [11]
RP   ALTERNATIVE SPLICING (ISOFORM GARP2).
RA   Cote R.H.;
RL   Unpublished observations (MAY-2009).
RN   [12]
RP   VARIANT RP45 VAL-993.
RX   PubMed=11379879; DOI=10.1007/s004390100496;
RA   Bareil C., Hamel C.P., Delague V., Arnaud B., Demaille J.,
RA   Claustres M.;
RT   "Segregation of a mutation in CNGB1 encoding the beta-subunit of the
RT   rod cGMP-gated channel in a family with autosomal recessive retinitis
RT   pigmentosa.";
RL   Hum. Genet. 108:328-334(2001).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Subunit of cyclic nucleotide-gated (CNG) channels,
CC       nonselective cation channels, which play important roles in both
CC       visual and olfactory signal transduction. When associated with
CC       CNGA1, it is involved in the regulation of ion flow into the rod
CC       photoreceptor outer segment (ROS), in response to light-induced
CC       alteration of the levels of intracellular cGMP.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Isoform GARP2 is a high affinity rod photoreceptor
CC       phosphodiesterase (PDE6)-binding protein that modulates its
CC       catalytic properties: it is a regulator of spontaneous activation
CC       of rod PDE6, thereby serving to lower rod photoreceptor 'dark
CC       noise' and allowing these sensory cells to operate at the single
CC       photon detection limit.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Tetramer formed of three CNGA1 and one CNGB1 modulatory
CC       subunits. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q5ICW4:GRB14 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-7959609, EBI-7639273;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC         Comment=There is no evidence for an ortholog to bovine GARP1 in
CC         the human genome.;
CC       Name=RCNC2B;
CC         IsoId=Q14028-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=RCNC2A;
CC         IsoId=Q14028-2; Sequence=VSP_001110;
CC       Name=GARP2; Synonyms=GARP;
CC         IsoId=Q14028-3; Sequence=VSP_037921, VSP_037922;
CC         Note=In the rod cells, the CNGB1 locus encodes the cyclic
CC         nucleotide-gated cation channel beta-1 subunit and several
CC         glutamic-acid-rich proteins (GARPs).;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q14028-4; Sequence=VSP_053421;
CC   -!- DISEASE: Retinitis pigmentosa 45 (RP45) [MIM:613767]: A retinal
CC       dystrophy belonging to the group of pigmentary retinopathies.
CC       Retinitis pigmentosa is characterized by retinal pigment deposits
CC       visible on fundus examination and primary loss of rod
CC       photoreceptor cells followed by secondary loss of cone
CC       photoreceptors. Patients typically have night vision blindness and
CC       loss of midperipheral visual field. As their condition progresses,
CC       they lose their far peripheral visual field and eventually central
CC       vision as well. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11379879}. Note=The disease is
CC       caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cyclic nucleotide-gated cation channel
CC       (TC 1.A.1.5) family. CNGB1 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=26875626; DOI=10.1016/j.neuron.2016.01.016;
RA   Hackos D.H., Lupardus P.J., Grand T., Chen Y., Wang T.M., Reynen P.,
RA   Gustafson A., Wallweber H.J., Volgraf M., Sellers B.D., Schwarz J.B.,
RA   Paoletti P., Sheng M., Zhou Q., Hanson J.E.;
RT   "Positive Allosteric Modulators of GluN2A-Containing NMDARs with
RT   Distinct Modes of Action and Impacts on Circuit Function.";
RL   Neuron 89:983-999(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of NMDA receptor complexes that function as
CC       heterotetrameric, ligand-gated ion channels with high calcium
CC       permeability and voltage-dependent sensitivity to magnesium.
CC       Channel activation requires binding of the neurotransmitter
CC       glutamate to the epsilon subunit, glycine binding to the zeta
CC       subunit, plus membrane depolarization to eliminate channel
CC       inhibition by Mg(2+) (PubMed:26875626). Sensitivity to glutamate
CC       and channel kinetics depend on the subunit composition (Probable).
CC       Plays a role in regulating the balance between excitatory and
CC       inhibitory activity of pyramidal neurons in the prefrontal cortex.
CC       Contributes to the slow phase of excitatory postsynaptic current,
CC       long-term synaptic potentiation, and learning (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q01098, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26875626,
CC       ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer. Forms heterotetrameric channels composed
CC       of two zeta subunits (GRIN1), and two epsilon subunits (GRIN2A,
CC       GRIN2B, GRIN2C or GRIN2D) (in vitro) (PubMed:26875626). In vivo,
CC       the subunit composition may depend on the expression levels of the
CC       different subunits (Probable). Interacts with PDZ domains of PATJ
CC       and DLG4 (By similarity). Interacts (via PDZ-binding motif) with
CC       SNX27 (via PDZ domain); the interaction is required for recycling
CC       to the plasma membrane when endocytosed and prevent degradation in
CC       lysosomes (PubMed:21300787). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q00961,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21300787, ECO:0000269|PubMed:26875626,
CC       ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q62936:Dlg3 (xeno); NbExp=6; IntAct=EBI-8285963, EBI-349596;
CC       P78352:DLG4; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-8285963, EBI-80389;
CC       P31016:Dlg4 (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-8285963, EBI-375655;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26875626};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Cell junction, synapse,
CC       postsynaptic cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Mainly expressed in brain with predominant
CC       expression is in the cerebellum, also present in the hippocampus,
CC       amygdala, caudate nucleus, corpus callosum, subthalamic nuclei and
CC       thalamus. Detected in the heart, skeletal muscle and pancreas.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9037519}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: A hydrophobic region that gives rise to the prediction of
CC       a transmembrane span does not cross the membrane, but is part of a
CC       discontinuously helical region that dips into the membrane and is
CC       probably part of the pore and of the selectivity filter.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q00960}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. NR2C/GRIN2C subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   VARIANTS ACHM2 ASP-323 AND HIS-569.
RX   PubMed=26493561; DOI=10.1186/s12967-015-0694-7;
RA   Li F.F., Huang X.F., Chen J., Yu X.D., Zheng M.Q., Lu F., Jin Z.B.,

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Visual signal transduction is mediated by a G-protein
CC       coupled cascade using cGMP as second messenger. This protein can
CC       be activated by cyclic GMP which leads to an opening of the cation
CC       channel and thereby causing a depolarization of cone
CC       photoreceptors. Induced a flickering channel gating, weakened the
CC       outward rectification in the presence of extracellular calcium,
CC       increased sensitivity for L-cis diltiazem and enhanced the cAMP
CC       efficacy of the channel when coexpressed with CNGB3 (By
CC       similarity). Essential for the generation of light-evoked
CC       electrical responses in the red-, green- and blue sensitive cones.
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10888875}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Tetramer formed of three CNGA3 and one CNGB3 modulatory
CC       subunits. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10888875,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15134637, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21878911}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q16281-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q16281-2; Sequence=VSP_042525;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q16281-3; Sequence=VSP_057075;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Prominently expressed in retina.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal coiled-coil domain mediates
CC       homotrimerization of CNGA subunits.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Achromatopsia 2 (ACHM2) [MIM:216900]: An ocular
CC       stationary disorder due to the absence of functioning cone
CC       photoreceptors in the retina. It is characterized by total
CC       colorblindness, low visual acuity, photophobia and nystagmus.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11536077, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14757870,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15712225, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15743887,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18521937, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24903488,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26493561, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9662398}. Note=The
CC       disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in
CC       this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cyclic nucleotide-gated cation channel
CC       (TC 1.A.1.5) family. CNGA3 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Mutations of the CNGA3 gene; Note=Retina
CC       International's Scientific Newsletter;
CC       URL="http://www.retina-international.org/files/sci-news/cnga3mut.htm";
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RC   STRAIN=Bristol N2;
RX   PubMed=17761667; DOI=10.1074/mcp.M600392-MCP200;
RA   Kaji H., Kamiie J., Kawakami H., Kido K., Yamauchi Y., Shinkawa T.,
RA   Taoka M., Takahashi N., Isobe T.;

RT   elegans and suggests an atypical translocation mechanism for integral
RT   membrane proteins.";
RL   Mol. Cell. Proteomics 6:2100-2109(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glutamate-gated chloride channel subunit; channel
CC       properties depend on the subunit composition. Glutamate binding
CC       triggers a rapidly reversible current in heteromeric channels
CC       formed by glc-1 and glc-2, while the anti-helmintic drug
CC       ivermectin and other avermectins trigger a permanently open
CC       channel configuration. Channels containing only glc-2 are
CC       activated by glutamate, but not by ivermectin (in vitro). The
CC       heteromeric channel formed by glc-1 and glc-2 is also activated by
CC       ibotenate, and it is blocked by picrotoxin and flufenamic acid
CC       (PubMed:7935817). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7935817}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pentamer (By similarity). Homooligomer that can form
CC       functional heterooligomers with glc-1 (PubMed:7935817).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:G5EBR3, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7935817}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q94900}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q94900}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000255, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7935817}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7935817}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Glutamate-gated chloride channel (TC 1.A.9.4) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RP   TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=26705699; DOI=10.7554/eLife.12432;
RA   Pereira L., Kratsios P., Serrano-Saiz E., Sheftel H., Mayo A.E.,
RA   Hall D.H., White J.G., LeBoeuf B., Garcia L.R., Alon U., Hobert O.;

RN   [4] {ECO:0000305}
RP   DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=27782882; DOI=10.7554/eLife.21734;
RA   Takayanagi-Kiya S., Zhou K., Jin Y.;
RT   "Release-dependent feedback inhibition by a presynaptically localized
RT   ligand-gated anion channel.";
RL   Elife 5:21734-21749(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acetylcholine-gated chloride channel subunit. Currents
CC       in channels are triggered in response to acetylcholine. Channel
CC       properties may be modulated by the formation of homomeric and
CC       heteromeric channels. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homopentamer (in vitro). May interact with either acc-3
CC       or acc-4; the interactions do not result in significant
CC       heteropentameric ion channel activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in RIA, RIG, PHA and AIZ
CC       glutamatergic neurons, URX and RIH cholinergic neurons, and in
CC       male-specific MCM neurons. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26705699}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Grossly normal movement.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=26705699; DOI=10.7554/eLife.12432;
RA   Pereira L., Kratsios P., Serrano-Saiz E., Sheftel H., Mayo A.E.,
RA   Hall D.H., White J.G., LeBoeuf B., Garcia L.R., Alon U., Hobert O.;

RN   [4] {ECO:0000305}
RP   DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=27782882; DOI=10.7554/eLife.21734;
RA   Takayanagi-Kiya S., Zhou K., Jin Y.;
RT   "Release-dependent feedback inhibition by a presynaptically localized
RT   ligand-gated anion channel.";
RL   Elife 5:21734-21749(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acetylcholine-gated chloride channel subunit. Forms
CC       functional homopentameric (in vitro) and functional
CC       heteropentameric ion channels with acc-3 and acc-4 ion channel
CC       subunits. Currents in channels are triggered in response to
CC       acetylcholine, but not in response to GABA, glutamate, glycine,
CC       histamine or dopamine. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homopentamer (in vitro). Forms heteropentamers composed
CC       of acc-1 and acc-4 or acc-1 and acc-3. Both homopentamers and
CC       heteropentamers form functional ion channels.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in a subset of cholinergic motor
CC       neurons including cholinergic motor neurons in the ventral cord,
CC       the retrovesicular ganglion and in head neurons such as the SMD,
CC       RMD motor neurons, the AVA and AVE command interneurons and the
CC       SAA neurons. Also expressed in a small number of glutamatergic
CC       neurons including the pharyngeal neurons MI and M3, the PLM
CC       neurons and a pair of neurons in the lateral ganglion.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26705699}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Grossly normal movement.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Approximately 50-fold more sensitive to cGMP than to
CC       cAMP. May be involved in transduction cascades of both
CC       invertebrate photoreceptors and olfactory sensillae.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7957070}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in antennae and the visual system.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7957070}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cyclic nucleotide-gated cation channel
CC       (TC 1.A.1.5) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RC   STRAIN=Berkeley;

RN   [4]
RP   FUNCTION, AND INTERACTION WITH LCCH3.
RX   PubMed=15148245; DOI=10.1038/sj.bjp.0705818;
RA   Gisselmann G., Plonka J., Pusch H., Hatt H.;
RT   "Drosophila melanogaster GRD and LCCH3 subunits form heteromultimeric
RT   GABA-gated cation channels.";
RL   Br. J. Pharmacol. 142:409-413(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, an inhibitory neurotransmitter, mediates neuronal
CC       inhibition by binding to the GABA receptor and opening an integral
CC       chloride channel. May combine with the ligand-gated ion channel
CC       subunit Lcch3 to form cation-selective GABA-gated ion channels.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15148245}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho. Interacts
CC       with Lcch3 (beta chain). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15148245}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor (TC 1.A.9.5) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RC   STRAIN=Berkeley {ECO:0000312|EMBL:AAL48048.1};
RC   TISSUE=Embryo {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12537569};

RP   FUNCTION, INTERACTION WITH NMDAR2, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, TISSUE
RP   SPECIFICITY, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=15823532; DOI=10.1016/j.cub.2005.02.059;
RA   Xia S., Miyashita T., Fu T.-F., Lin W.-Y., Wu C.-L., Pyzocha L.,
RA   Lin I.-R., Saitoe M., Tully T., Chiang A.-S.;
RT   "NMDA receptors mediate olfactory learning and memory in Drosophila.";
RL   Curr. Biol. 15:603-615(2005).
RN   [7] {ECO:0000305}
RP   GLYCOSYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT ASN-693, AND IDENTIFICATION BY
RP   MASS SPECTROMETRY.
RC   STRAIN=Oregon-R; TISSUE=Head {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17893096};
RX   PubMed=17893096; DOI=10.1093/glycob/cwm097;
RA   Koles K., Lim J.-M., Aoki K., Porterfield M., Tiemeyer M., Wells L.,
RA   Panin V.;
RT   "Identification of N-glycosylated proteins from the central nervous
RT   system of Drosophila melanogaster.";
RL   Glycobiology 17:1388-1403(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: NMDA receptor subtype of glutamate-gated ion channels
CC       with high calcium permeability and voltage-dependent sensitivity
CC       to magnesium. Mediated by glycine. This protein plays a key role
CC       in synaptic plasticity, synaptogenesis, excitotoxicity, memory
CC       acquisition and learning. It mediates neuronal functions in
CC       glutamate neurotransmission. Is involved in the cell surface
CC       targeting of NMDA receptors. Plays a role in associative learning
CC       and in long-term memory consolidation.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P35439, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15823532}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms a heteromeric NMDA channel with Nmdar2.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15823532};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15823532}. Cell
CC       junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15823532}. Cell junction, synapse,
CC       postsynaptic cell membrane, postsynaptic density
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15823532}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in adult heads: in the brain
CC       and ring gland. Low expression throughout the entire brain is also
CC       seen. Higher expression levels were observed in some scattered
CC       cell bodies and part of their fibers, including those from several
CC       pairs of DPM (dorsal-posterior-medial) neurons surrounding the
CC       calyx, DAL (dorsal-anterior-lateral) and DPL (dorsal-posterior-
CC       lateral) neurons in the lateral protocerebrum (LP), VAL (ventral-
CC       anterior-lateral) neurons in the anterior protocerebrum, and two
CC       pairs of VP (ventral-posterior) neurons in the posterior
CC       protocerebrum. Many cell bodies in the optic lobes show
CC       preferential expression. Punctuate expression is notably detected
CC       in many brain regions including the superior medial protocerebrum.
CC       Weakly expressed in the antennal lobes and central complex.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11773617, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15823532,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8508917}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expression first seen in late embryos. Levels
CC       are low during larval development and increase in late pupae to
CC       persist through to adulthood. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8508917}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Flies exhibit disruption of olfactory
CC       learning. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15823532}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RP   BY MASS SPECTROMETRY.
RC   TISSUE=Embryo;
RX   PubMed=18327897; DOI=10.1021/pr700696a;
