CC   -!- FUNCTION: Intracellular calcium channel that is required for
CC       proper muscle function during embryonic development and may be
CC       essential for excitation-contraction coupling in larval body wall
CC       muscles. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10811919,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8276118}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Note=The
CC       number of predicted transmembrane domains varies between
CC       orthologs, but both N-terminus and C-terminus seem to be
CC       cytoplasmic. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC       Name=A {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8276118};
CC         IsoId=Q24498-2; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=B {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8276118};
CC         IsoId=Q24498-3; Sequence=VSP_050196;
CC       Name=C {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8276118};
CC         IsoId=Q24498-4; Sequence=VSP_050195;
CC       Name=D {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8276118};
CC         IsoId=Q24498-5; Sequence=VSP_050195, VSP_050196;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: During embryonic stages 9-10, expression is
CC       seen in mesoderm of all segments in progenitors of the cephalic
CC       and somatic muscles. Adults exhibit high expression in tubular
CC       'jump' muscles of thorax and leg, and lower expression in the
CC       brain, ventral ganglion, head muscles and proboscis muscles.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10811919, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1338312,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8276118}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Abundant in 6-12 hours embryos, reduced
CC       expression in second and third instar larval stages and adults.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1338312, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8276118}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The calcium release channel activity resides in the C-
CC       terminal region while the remaining part of the protein resides in
CC       the cytoplasm. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Channel activity is modulated by the alkaloid
CC       ryanodine that binds to the open Ca-release channel with high
CC       affinity and maintains the channel in an open conformation. The
CC       calcium release channel is modulated by calcium ions, magnesium
CC       ions, ATP and calmodulin (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ryanodine receptor (TC 1.A.3.1) family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RC   STRAIN=Bristol N2;
RX   PubMed=17761667; DOI=10.1074/mcp.M600392-MCP200;
RA   Kaji H., Kamiie J., Kawakami H., Kido K., Yamauchi Y., Shinkawa T.,

RL   Mol. Cell. Proteomics 6:2100-2109(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Non-alpha subunit of nicotinic acetylcholine receptor
CC       (nAChR). Involved in nAChR sensitivity to nicotine.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990870}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with unc-29. Component of nicotinic
CC       acetylcholine receptor composed of 2 non-alpha subunits lev-1 and
CC       unc-29, and 3 alpha subunits unc-38, unc-63 and lev-8.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990870}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990870}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990870}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}. Note=Co-localizes with unc-29 and unc-38 at nerve
CC       cord synapses. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990870}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: RNAi-mediated knockdown causes a resistance
CC       to nicotine-mediated paralysis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990870}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=15961431; DOI=10.1113/jphysiol.2005.088435;
RA   Cockayne D.A., Dunn P.M., Zhong Y., Rong W., Hamilton S.G.,
RA   Knight G.E., Ruan H.Z., Ma B., Yip P., Nunn P., McMahon S.B.,

RT   "P2X2 knockout mice and P2X2/P2X3 double knockout mice reveal a role

RN   [5]
RP   DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=16322458; DOI=10.1126/science.1118435;
RA   Finger T.E., Danilova V., Barrows J., Bartel D.L., Vigers A.J.,
RA   Stone L., Hellekant G., Kinnamon S.C.;
RT   "ATP signaling is crucial for communication from taste buds to
RT   gustatory nerves.";
RL   Science 310:1495-1499(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Receptor for ATP that acts as a ligand-gated ion
CC       channel. {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15961431}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Functional P2XRs are organized as homomeric and
CC       heteromeric trimers. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Simultaneous knockout of P2rx2 and P2rx3
CC       results in reduced pain-related behaviors in response to
CC       intraplantar injection of formalin and reduced urinary bladder
CC       reflexes and decreased pelvic afferent nerve activity in response
CC       to bladder distension. Neurons have minimal to no response to ATP
CC       (PubMed:15961431). Simultaneous knockout of P2rx2 and P2rx3
CC       results in defects in taste responses in the taste nerves and
CC       reduced behavioral responses to sweeteners, glutamate and bitter
CC       substances (PubMed:16322458). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15961431,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16322458}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the P2X receptor family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [2]
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=18486207; DOI=10.1016/j.ceca.2008.04.001;
RA   Ludlow M.J., Traynor D., Fisher P.R., Ennion S.J.;
RT   "Purinergic-mediated Ca2+ influx in Dictyostelium discoideum.";
RL   Cell Calcium 44:567-579(2008).
RN   [3]
RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=19833731; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M109.045674;
RA   Ludlow M.J., Durai L., Ennion S.J.;
RT   "Functional characterization of intracellular Dictyostelium discoideum
RT   P2X receptors.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 284:35227-35239(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: P2X receptors are ATP-gated ion channels that play a
CC       role in intracellular calcium signaling. Not required for the
CC       purinergic response to extracellular nucleotides. Not essential
CC       for osmoregulation. Inward currents evoked by intracellular ATP.
CC       ATP analog beta, gamma-imido-ATP is a weak partial agonist of
CC       p2xE. Exclusively selective for ATP over other nucleotides.
CC       Insensitive to copper and P2 receptor antagonists PPADS and
CC       suramin but strongly inhibited by sodium ions. More permeable to
CC       ammonium than either sodium or potassium ions and less permeable
CC       to choline. Permeable to calcium ions, but not chloride.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18486207, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19833731}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Contractile vacuole membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19833731}. Note=Ligand binding domain within
CC       the lumen of the vacuole.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Response to extracellular ATP remains the
CC       same in p2xE null strains. Null cells are still capable of
CC       osmoregulation and do not show any noticeable differences in their
CC       sensitivity to hypotonic conditions. Quintuple
CC       p2xA/p2xB/p2xC/p2xD/p2xE null cells displayed slight delay in
CC       their osmoregulatory response, but are still capable of regulating
CC       their cell volume in water. Extracellular purinergic response to
CC       ATP persists in the quintuple null cells with no alteration in the
CC       kinetics of the response, but the magnitude of the response is
CC       lower. Responses to the calmodulin antagonist calmidazolium are
CC       reduced and intracellular calcium signaling is disrupted in
CC       quintuple null cells. The presence of copper prevented both wild
CC       type and quintuple null cells from undergoing an osmoregulatory
CC       decrease in cell volume. No obvious morphological phenotype was
CC       apparent in the p2xE or quintuple p2x null strains. The quintuple
CC       p2x null strains grow slightly slower than wild type in shaking
CC       axenic cultures. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18486207,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19833731}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the P2X receptor family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Receptor for ATP that acts as a ligand-gated ion
CC       channel. This receptor is insensitive to the antagonists PPADS and
CC       suramin (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Functional P2XRs are organized as homomeric and
CC       heteromeric trimers. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the P2X receptor family. {ECO:0000305}.

DE            Short=GluK1;

DE            Short=GluR-5;

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [GENOMIC DNA] OF 584-695, AND RNA EDITING OF
RP   POSITION 621.
RC   STRAIN=BALB/cJ;
RX   PubMed=8700852; DOI=10.1073/pnas.93.5.1875;
RA   Herb A., Higuchi M., Sprengel R., Seeburg P.H.;
RT   "Q/R site editing in kainate receptor GluR5 and GluR6 pre-mRNAs
RT   requires distant intronic sequences.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 93:1875-1880(1996).
RN   [3]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE OF 606-622, AND RNA EDITING OF POSITION 621.
RX   PubMed=1717158; DOI=10.1016/0092-8674(91)90568-J;
RA   Sommer B., Koehler M., Sprengel R., Seeburg P.H.;
RT   "RNA editing in brain controls a determinant of ion flow in glutamate-
RT   gated channels.";
RL   Cell 67:11-19(1991).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ionotropic glutamate receptor. L-glutamate acts as an
CC       excitatory neurotransmitter at many synapses in the central
CC       nervous system. Binding of the excitatory neurotransmitter L-
CC       glutamate induces a conformation change, leading to the opening of
CC       the cation channel, and thereby converts the chemical signal to an
CC       electrical impulse. The receptor then desensitizes rapidly and
CC       enters a transient inactive state, characterized by the presence
CC       of bound agonist. May be involved in the transmission of light
CC       information from the retina to the hypothalamus (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer or heterotetramer of pore-forming glutamate
CC       receptor subunits. Tetramers may be formed by the dimerization of
CC       dimers (Probable). The unedited version (Q) assembles into a
CC       functional kainate-gated homomeric channel, whereas the edited
CC       version (R) is unable to produce channel activity when expressed
CC       alone. Both edited and unedited versions can form functional
CC       channels with GRIK4 and GRIK5. Interacts with KLHL17 (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC       Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=1;
CC         Comment=At least 2 isoforms are produced.;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q60934-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Most abundant in the cerebellum. Also present
CC       in the suprachiasmatic nuclei of the hypothalamus.
CC   -!- RNA EDITING: Modified_positions=621 {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1717158,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8700852}; Note=Partially edited.;
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The postsynaptic actions of Glu are mediated by a
CC       variety of receptors that are named according to their selective
CC       agonists. This receptor binds domoate > kainate > L-glutamate =
CC       quisqualate > CNQX = DNQX > AMPA > dihydrokainate > NMDA (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. GRIK1 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

CC   -!- FUNCTION: After binding acetylcholine, the AChR responds by an
CC       extensive change in conformation that affects all subunits and
CC       leads to opening of an ion-conducting channel across the plasma
CC       membrane. Nicotinic acetylcholine receptor in the MC pharyngeal
CC       motor neuron involved in pharyngeal pumping. Has a role in the
CC       determination of life span possibly via calorific restriction
CC       which affects growth rate, although this is independent of
CC       metabolic activity (By similarity). {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P22770,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9U298}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Neuronal AChR seems to be composed of two different type
CC       of subunits: alpha and beta. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P22770}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000250}. Note=MC motor neuron.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9U298}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Church D.M., Goodstadt L., Hillier L.W., Zody M.C., Goldstein S.,

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE GENOMIC DNA].
RA   Mural R.J., Adams M.D., Myers E.W., Smith H.O., Venter J.C.;
RL   Submitted (JUL-2005) to the EMBL/GenBank/DDBJ databases.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Receptor for glutamate. L-glutamate acts as an
CC       excitatory neurotransmitter at many synapses in the central
CC       nervous system. The postsynaptic actions of Glu are mediated by a
CC       variety of receptors that are named according to their selective
CC       agonists. This receptor binds kainate > quisqualate = glutamate >>
CC       AMPA.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Tetramer of two or more different subunits. Associates
CC       with GRIK1 (both edited and unedited versions), GRIK2, or GRIK3 to
CC       form functional channels. Homomeric associations do not produce
CC       any channel activity (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC       Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. GRIK5 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Elegheert J., Kakegawa W., Clay J.E., Shanks N.F., Behiels E.,
RA   Matsuda K., Kohda K., Miura E., Rossmann M., Mitakidis N.,

RT   organizer complexes.";
RL   Science 353:295-299(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Receptor for glutamate. L-glutamate acts as an
CC       excitatory neurotransmitter at many synapses in the central
CC       nervous system. The postsynaptic actions of Glu are mediated by a
CC       variety of receptors that are named according to their selective
CC       agonists.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Dimer (PubMed:27418511). Interacts (via extracellular N-
CC       terminal domain) with CBLN1 (via C1q domain), and more weakly with
CC       CBLN2 (PubMed:22220752, PubMed:27418511).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:22220752, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27418511}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000250}. Cell junction, synapse,
CC       postsynaptic cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Equally in forebrain and cerebellum.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:1372507}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. GRID1 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Hansen K.B., Tajima N., Risgaard R., Perszyk R.E., Jorgensen L.,
RA   Vance K.M., Ogden K.K., Clausen R.P., Furukawa H., Traynelis S.F.;

RT   site of N-methyl-D-aspartate receptors.";
RL   Mol. Pharmacol. 84:114-127(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of NMDA receptor complexes that function as
CC       heterotetrameric, ligand-gated ion channels with high calcium
CC       permeability and voltage-dependent sensitivity to magnesium.
CC       Channel activation requires binding of the neurotransmitter
CC       glutamate to the epsilon subunit, glycine binding to the zeta
CC       subunit, plus membrane depolarization to eliminate channel
CC       inhibition by Mg(2+) (PubMed:7512349, PubMed:21522138,
CC       PubMed:23625947). Sensitivity to glutamate and channel kinetics
CC       depend on the subunit composition (PubMed:7512349,
CC       PubMed:23625947). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21522138,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23625947, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7512349,
CC       ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer. Forms heterotetrameric channels composed
CC       of two zeta subunits (GRIN1), and two epsilon subunits (GRIN2A,
CC       GRIN2B, GRIN2C or GRIN2D) (in vitro) (PubMed:21522138,
CC       PubMed:23625947). In vivo, the subunit composition may depend on
CC       the expression levels of the different subunits (Probable).
CC       Interacts with PDZ domains of PATJ and DLG4 (PubMed:7569905,
CC       PubMed:9647694). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21522138,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23625947, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7569905,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9647694, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q63ZW7:Patj (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-631067, EBI-8366894;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:21522138,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23625947, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7512349}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}. Cell junction, synapse,
CC       postsynaptic cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q62645-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q62645-2; Sequence=VSP_000136;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in brain, mainly in the subcortical
CC       region.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Already detected in embryonic stages, peaks
CC       at postnatal day 7, and decreases thereafter to adult levels.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: A hydrophobic region that gives rise to the prediction of
CC       a transmembrane span does not cross the membrane, but is part of a
CC       discontinuously helical region that dips into the membrane and is
CC       probably part of the pore and of the selectivity filter.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q00960}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. NR2D/GRIN2D subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Receptor for inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate, a second
CC       messenger that mediates the release of intracellular calcium.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. Interacts with TRPC1, TRPC3, TRPC4.
CC       Interacts with TRPV4 (By similarity). Interacts with SIGMAR1
CC       (PubMed:11149946). Interacts with AKT1 and PML. Interacts with
CC       LRMP (via coiled-coil domain) (By similarity). Interacts with
CC       CABP1 (PubMed:12032348). Interacts with TMBIM4/LFG4 (By
CC       similarity). Interacts with CEMIP (By similarity). Interacts with
CC       TESPA1 (By similarity). Interacts with TMEM203 (By similarity).
CC       Interacts with BOK; regulates ITPR3 expression (PubMed:23884412).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P70227, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q14573,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11149946, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12032348,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23884412}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The receptor contains a calcium channel in its C-terminal
CC       extremity. Its large N-terminal cytoplasmic region has the ligand-
CC       binding site in the N-terminus and modulatory sites in the middle
CC       portion immediately upstream of the channel region.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated on tyrosine residues. Phosphorylated by AKT1
CC       on serine and/or threonine residues (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the InsP3 receptor family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   SUBUNITS.
RX   PubMed=15134638; DOI=10.1016/S0896-6273(04)00253-3;
RA   Zheng J., Zagotta W.N.;
RT   "Stoichiometry and assembly of olfactory cyclic nucleotide-gated
RT   channels.";
RL   Neuron 42:411-421(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Second messenger, cAMP, causes the opening of cation-
CC       selective cyclic nucleotide-gated (CNG) channels and
CC       depolarization of the neuron (olfactory sensory neurons, OSNs).
CC       CNGA4 is the modulatory subunit of this channel which is known to
CC       play a central role in the transduction of odorant signals and
CC       subsequent adaptation. By accelerating the calcium-mediated
CC       negative feedback in olfactory signaling it allows rapid
CC       adaptation to odor stimulation and extends its range of odor
CC       detection (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Calcium-calmodulin exerts its inhibitory effect
CC       in cAMP sensitivity by binding to IQ-like motif of CNGA4 and
CC       preferably binds to the channel in the closed state. Inhibition by
CC       PIP3 of the CNG channel probably occurs via CGNA2 binding.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15195096}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterotetramer composed of two subunits of CNGA2, one of
CC       CNGA4 and one of CNGB1b. The complex forms the cyclic nucleotide-
CC       gated (CNG) channel of olfactory sensory neurons.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15134638}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Olfactory neurons.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal coiled-coil domain mediates trimerization
CC       of CNGA subunits. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cyclic nucleotide-gated cation channel
CC       (TC 1.A.1.5) family. CNGA4 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RN   [4]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA] (ISOFORMS 2 AND 3), AND
RP   VARIANTS HIS-225 AND HIS-435.
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: This is one of the several different receptors for 5-
CC       hydroxytryptamine (serotonin), a biogenic hormone that functions
CC       as a neurotransmitter, a hormone, and a mitogen. This receptor is
CC       a ligand-gated ion channel, which when activated causes fast,
CC       depolarizing responses. It is a cation-specific, but otherwise
CC       relatively nonselective, ion channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms a pentaheteromeric complex with HTR3A. Not
CC       functional as a homomeric complex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17392525}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P46098:HTR3A; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-9008717, EBI-9008743;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17392525};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17392525}.
CC       Note=Presumably retained within the endoplasmic reticulum unless
CC       complexed with HTR3A.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q70Z44-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q70Z44-2; Sequence=VSP_029798, VSP_029799, VSP_029801;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q70Z44-3; Sequence=VSP_029797, VSP_029800, VSP_029801;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q70Z44-4; Sequence=VSP_044828, VSP_044829, VSP_044830,
CC                                  VSP_029801;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in liver, as well as fetal and adult
CC       colon and kidney. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12801637}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. 5-hydroxytryptamine receptor (TC 1.A.9.2) subfamily. HTR3D
CC       sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (3.30 ANGSTROMS) OF 44-359 IN COMPLEXES WITH
RP   PROPOFOL AND DESFLURANE ANESTHETICS, AND MUTAGENESIS OF ILE-244;
RP   VAL-284 AND THR-297.
RC   STRAIN=PCC 7421;
RX   PubMed=21248852; DOI=10.1038/nature09647;
RA   Nury H., Van Renterghem C., Weng Y., Tran A., Baaden M., Dusfresne V.,
RA   Changeux J.P., Sonner J.M., Delarue M., Corringer P.J.;
RT   "X-ray structures of general anaesthetics bound to a pentameric
RT   ligand-gated ion channel.";
RL   Nature 469:428-431(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cationic channel with similar permeabilities for Na(+)
CC       and K(+), that is activated by an increase of the proton
CC       concentration on the extracellular side. Displays no permeability
CC       for chloride ions. Shows slow kinetics of activation, no
CC       desensitization and a single channel conductance of 8 pS. Might
CC       contribute to adaptation to external pH change.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17167423}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Tetraethylammonium (TEA) and tetrabutylammonium
CC       (TBA) inhibit the proton-activated currents in a dose- and
CC       voltage-dependent manner in vitro, whereas the blocker of acid
CC       sensing ion channels, amiloride, has no effect. Channel current of
CC       GLIC can be inhibited by inhaled and intravenous general
CC       anesthetics at and below concentrations used clinically. Ion
CC       conduction is also inhibited by lidocaine and by divalent
CC       transition metal ions such as cadmium ions.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17167423, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19933531,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21037567}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homopentamer. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17167423,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18987630, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18987633}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=26; IntAct=EBI-8423601, EBI-8423601;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Consists of an N-terminal ligand-binding domain that
CC       encloses a wide aqueous vestibule and a transmembrane domain that
CC       forms a narrow channel.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The homologous nature of GLIC to eukaryotic
CC       nicotinic acetylcholine receptors and other eukaryotic pentameric
CC       ligand-gated ion channels, and its sensitivity to general
CC       anesthetics, define GLIC as a structural and functional model of
CC       signal transduction in the nervous system, also relevant for
CC       exploring the molecular basis of anesthetic action.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glutamate-gated receptor that probably acts as non-
CC       selective cation channel. May be involved in light-signal
CC       transduction and calcium homeostasis via the regulation of calcium
CC       influx into cells. Required for the long-term calcium oscillation-
CC       regulated stomatal movements. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19143998}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: May form heteromers. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed predominantly in roots. Firt
CC       detected in the vascular tissues of the cotyledons, and later in
CC       the vasculature of all organs. In leaves, preferentially expressed
CC       in guard cells. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12082126,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19143998}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:

RP   GENOME REANNOTATION.
RC   STRAIN=cv. Nipponbare;
RX   PubMed=24280374; DOI=10.1186/1939-8433-6-4;
RA   Kawahara Y., de la Bastide M., Hamilton J.P., Kanamori H.,

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glutamate-gated receptor that probably acts as non-
CC       selective cation channel. Involved in root development. May
CC       regulate cell proliferation and cell death in the root apex.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16377757}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: May form homomultimers. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16377757}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed at low levels in roots and leaves.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16377757}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By abiotic stresses.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Plants are defective in root elongation and
CC       show reduced mitotic activity and increased cell death in the root
CC       apical meristem (RAM). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16377757}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cation channel essential for the depolarizing
CC       photoresponse of retinal ON bipolar cells. It is part of the GRM6
CC       signaling cascade. May play a role in metastasis suppression (By
CC       similarity). May act as a spontaneously active, calcium-permeable
CC       plasma membrane channel. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11535825, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19878917,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19896109}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000255}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000255, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11535825}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=7;
CC       Name=1 {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16572171};
CC         IsoId=Q7Z4N2-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available. {ECO:0000305};
CC       Name=2 {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9806836, ECO:0000269|Ref.3};
CC         IsoId=Q7Z4N2-2; Sequence=VSP_052748;
CC       Name=3 {ECO:0000269|Ref.3};
CC         IsoId=Q7Z4N2-3; Sequence=VSP_052749;
CC       Name=4 {ECO:0000269|Ref.3};
CC         IsoId=Q7Z4N2-4; Sequence=VSP_052750;
CC         Note=May be produced at very low levels due to a premature stop
CC         codon in the mRNA, leading to nonsense-mediated mRNA decay.;
CC       Name=5;
CC         IsoId=Q7Z4N2-5; Sequence=VSP_046786;
CC       Name=6;
CC         IsoId=Q7Z4N2-6; Sequence=VSP_046787;
CC       Name=7;
CC         IsoId=Q7Z4N2-7; Sequence=VSP_046788, VSP_046789;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the retina where it localizes to
CC       the outer plexiform layer. Highly expressed in benign melanocytic
CC       nevi and diffusely expressed in various in situ melanomas, but not
CC       detected in melanoma metastases. Also expressed in melanocytes and
CC       pigmented metastatic melanoma cell lines. In melanocytes
CC       expression appears to be regulated at the level of transcription
CC       and mRNA processing. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11112417,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19896109, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9537257}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Up-regulated by hexamethylene bisacetamide (HBMA).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11112417}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Night blindness, congenital stationary, 1C (CSNB1C)
CC       [MIM:613216]: A non-progressive retinal disorder characterized by
CC       impaired night vision, often associated with nystagmus and myopia.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19878917, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19896109,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19896113}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       LTrpC subfamily. TRPM1 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=18486207; DOI=10.1016/j.ceca.2008.04.001;
RA   Ludlow M.J., Traynor D., Fisher P.R., Ennion S.J.;
RT   "Purinergic-mediated Ca2+ influx in Dictyostelium discoideum.";
RL   Cell Calcium 44:567-579(2008).
RN   [5]
RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=19833731; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M109.045674;
RA   Ludlow M.J., Durai L., Ennion S.J.;
RT   "Functional characterization of intracellular Dictyostelium discoideum
RT   P2X receptors.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 284:35227-35239(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: P2X receptors are ATP-gated ion channels that play a
CC       role in intracellular calcium signaling. Not required for the
CC       purinergic response to extracellular nucleotides. Inward currents
CC       evoked by intracellular ATP and ATP analogs. Exclusively selective
CC       for ATP over other nucleotides. Insensitive to P2 receptor
CC       antagonists PPADS, suramin and 2',3'-O-(2,4,6-trinitrophenyl)-ATP
CC       but inhibited by nanomolar concentrations of copper and sodium
CC       ion. More permeable to ammonium than either sodium or potassium
CC       ions and less permeable to choline. It has been reported that p2xA
CC       is not essential for osmoregulation (PubMed:19833731), however
CC       this information is in contradiction with another source
CC       (PubMed:17625565) which indicates that p2xA is required for
CC       osmoregulation. Found to be permeable to chloride ions. Inhibited
CC       by copper and sodium ions. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17625565,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18486207, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19833731}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Contractile vacuole membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17625565, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19833731}.
CC       Note=Ligand binding domain within the lumen of the vacuole.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Response to extracellular ATP remains the
CC       same in p2xA null strains. p2xA null cells have been reported to
CC       have compromised contractile vacuoles and defective
CC       osmoregulation, and exhibit cell swelling (PubMed:17625565). This
CC       is contradictory to other reports (PubMed:19833731). Quintuple
CC       p2xA/p2xB/p2XC/p2xd/p2xE null cells exhibit a slight delay in
CC       their osmoregulatory response, but are ultimately still capable of
CC       regulating their cell volume in water. Extracellular purinergic
CC       response to ATP persists in the quintuple null cells with no
CC       alteration in the kinetics of the response, but the magnitude of
CC       the response is lower. Responses to the calmodulin antagonist
CC       calmidazolium are reduced and intracellular calcium signaling is
CC       disrupted in quintuple null cells. The presence of copper prevents
CC       both wild type and quintuple null cells from undergoing an
CC       osmoregulatory decrease in cell volume. The quintuple null strains
CC       grow slightly slower than wild type in shaking axenic cultures.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17625565, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18486207,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19833731}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the P2X receptor family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RA   Zanetti M., Lo Schiavo F., Zoratti M., Szabo I.;
RT   "Dual localization of plant glutamate receptor AtGLR3.4 to plastids
RT   and plasmamembrane.";
RL   Biochim. Biophys. Acta 1807:359-367(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glutamate-gated receptor that probably acts as non-
CC       selective cation channel, at least in hypocotyls. Can be triggered
CC       by Ala, Asn, Gly, Ser and, to a lower extent, Cys and Glu. May be
CC       involved in light-signal transduction and calcium homeostasis via
CC       the regulation of calcium influx into cells. Plays an important
CC       role in the calcium-based fast transmission of environmental
CC       stress. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15864638, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18162597,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21110940}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: May form heteromers. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC       Plastid, chloroplast.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=GLR3.4a;
CC         IsoId=Q8GXJ4-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=GLR3.4b;
CC         IsoId=Q8GXJ4-2; Sequence=VSP_009219, VSP_009220;
CC         Note=May be due to an intron retention. No experimental
CC         confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in seedlings, cotyledons, roots
CC       (e.g. root hairs, epidermis and cortex cells), stems, leaves (e.g.
CC       vascular bundles and hydathodes), and siliques.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12082126, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15864638}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: The induction by glutamate, gamma-amino butiric acid
CC       (GABA), malate, aspartate, acetate, wounding, touch, and cold
CC       stress stimuli is abscisic acid (ABA)-independent, but calcium-
CC       dependent. Cold-mediated induction is rapid but transient.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15864638}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Impaired glutamate-triggered (and Ala, Asn,
CC       Cys, Gly, Ser-triggered) membrane depolarization and calcium rise.
CC       Slight reduction of photosynthetic yield of Photosystem II.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18162597, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21110940}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAB71458.1; Type=Erroneous gene model prediction; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=AAD47833.1; Type=Erroneous termination; Positions=953; Note=Translated as Ser.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glutamate-gated receptor that probably acts as non-
CC       selective cation channel. Can transport calcium ions. May be
CC       involved in light-signal transduction and calcium homeostasis via
CC       the regulation of calcium influx into cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18625242}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: May form heteromers. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed predominantly in roots and siliques.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12082126}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   IDENTIFICATION, AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=11735224; DOI=10.1006/geno.2001.6666;
RA   Andersson O., Stenqvist A., Attersand A., von Euler G.;
RT   "Nucleotide sequence, genomic organization, and chromosomal
RT   localization of genes encoding the human NMDA receptor subunits NR3A
RT   and NR3B.";
RL   Genomics 78:178-184(2001).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: NMDA receptor subtype of glutamate-gated ion channels
CC       with reduced single-channel conductance, low calcium permeability
CC       and low voltage-dependent sensitivity to magnesium. Mediated by
CC       glycine.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms heteromeric channel of a zeta subunit (GRIN1), a
CC       epsilon subunit (GRIN2A, GRIN2B, GRIN2C or GRIN2D) and a third
CC       subunit (GRIN3A or GRIN3B). Does not form functional homomeric
CC       channels. Found in a complex containing GRIN1 and GRIN2A (By
CC       similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000250}. Cell junction, synapse,
CC       postsynaptic cell membrane {ECO:0000250}. Note=Requires the
CC       presence of GRIN1 to be targeted at the plasma membrane.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the hippocampus, the corpus
CC       callosum, in the facial and trigeminal nuclei of the brainstem and
CC       the ventral horn of the spinal cord. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11735224,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11823786}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. NR3B/GRIN3B subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Niesler B., Walstab J., Combrink S., Moeller D., Kapeller J.,
RA   Rietdorf J., Boenisch H., Goethert M., Rappold G., Bruess M.;

RN   [5]
RP   VARIANT [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] MET-128.
RX   PubMed=16959974; DOI=10.1126/science.1133427;
RA   Sjoeblom T., Jones S., Wood L.D., Parsons D.W., Lin J., Barber T.D.,
RA   Mandelker D., Leary R.J., Ptak J., Silliman N., Szabo S.,
RA   Buckhaults P., Farrell C., Meeh P., Markowitz S.D., Willis J.,
RA   Dawson D., Willson J.K.V., Gazdar A.F., Hartigan J., Wu L., Liu C.,
RA   Parmigiani G., Park B.H., Bachman K.E., Papadopoulos N.,
RA   Vogelstein B., Kinzler K.W., Velculescu V.E.;
RT   "The consensus coding sequences of human breast and colorectal
RT   cancers.";
RL   Science 314:268-274(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: This is one of the several different receptors for 5-
CC       hydroxytryptamine (serotonin), a biogenic hormone that functions
CC       as a neurotransmitter, a hormone, and a mitogen. This receptor is
CC       a ligand-gated ion channel, which when activated causes fast,
CC       depolarizing responses. It is a cation-specific, but otherwise
CC       relatively nonselective, ion channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms a pentaheteromeric complex with HTR3A. Not
CC       functional as a homomeric complex. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17392525}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P46098:HTR3A; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-9008753, EBI-9008743;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17392525};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17392525}.
CC       Note=Presumably retained within the endoplasmic reticulum unless
CC       complexed with HTR3A.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in many tissues including adult
CC       brain, colon, intestine, lung, muscle and stomach as well as fetal
CC       colon and kidney. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12801637}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. 5-hydroxytryptamine receptor (TC 1.A.9.2) subfamily. HTR3C
CC       sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Receptor for glutamate. L-glutamate acts as an
CC       excitatory neurotransmitter at many synapses in the central
CC       nervous system. The postsynaptic actions of Glu are mediated by a
CC       variety of receptors that are named according to their selective
CC       agonists (By similarity). This receptor binds domoate > kainate >
CC       AMPA > NBQX > glutamate. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homomeric.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC       Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: NMDA receptor subtype of glutamate-gated ion channels
CC       with reduced single-channel conductance, low calcium permeability
CC       and low voltage-dependent sensitivity to magnesium. Mediated by
CC       glycine.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms heteromeric channel of a zeta subunit (GRIN1), a
CC       epsilon subunit (GRIN2A, GRIN2B, GRIN2C or GRIN2D) and a third
CC       subunit (GRIN3A or GRIN3B). Does not form functional homomeric
CC       channels. Found in a complex with GRIN1 and GRIN2A or GRIN2B.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12008020, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14602821}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14602821};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14602821}. Cell
CC       junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14602821}. Note=Requires the presence of GRIN1
CC       to be targeted at the plasma membrane.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the facial nucleus and the
CC       ambiguus nucleus of the brainstem, pons, medulla, spinal cord and
CC       cerebellum. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11717388,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12008020, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14602821}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. NR3B/GRIN3B subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RA   Xiao Z., Guo W., Sun B., Hunt D.J., Wei J., Liu Y., Wang Y., Wang R.,
RA   Jones P.P., Back T.G., Chen S.R.;
RT   "Enhanced cytosolic Ca2+ activation underlies a common defect of
RT   central domain cardiac ryanodine receptor mutations linked to
RT   arrhythmias.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 291:24528-24537(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium channel that mediates the release of Ca(2+) from
CC       the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm and thereby plays a
CC       key role in triggering cardiac muscle contraction. Aberrant
CC       channel activation can lead to cardiac arrhythmia. In cardiac
CC       myocytes, calcium release is triggered by increased Ca(2+) levels
CC       due to activation of the L-type calcium channel CACNA1C. The
CC       calcium channel activity is modulated by formation of
CC       heterotetramers with RYR3. Required for cellular calcium ion
CC       homeostasis. Required for embryonic heart development.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10830164, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20056922,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27733687}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Channel activity is modulated by the alkaloid
CC       ryanodine that binds to the open Ca-release channel with high
CC       affinity. At low concentrations, ryanodine maintains the channel
CC       in an open conformation. High ryanodine concentrations inhibit
CC       channel activity. Channel activity is regulated by calmodulin
CC       (CALM). The calcium release is activated by increased cytoplasmic
CC       calcium levels, by nitric oxyde (NO), caffeine and ATP. Channel
CC       activity is inhibited by magnesium ions, possibly by competition
CC       for calcium binding sites. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P11716}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. Can also form heterotetramers with RYR1 and
CC       RYR3 (By similarity). Interacts with FKBP1A and FKBP1B; these
CC       interactions may stabilize the channel in its closed state and
CC       prevent Ca(2+) leaks. Interacts with CALM and S100A1; these
CC       interactions regulate channel activity. Identified in a complex
CC       composed of RYR2, FKBP1B, PKA catalytic subunit, PRKAR2A, AKAP6,
CC       and the protein phosphatases PP2A and PP1. Interacts directly with
CC       FKBP1B, PKA, PP1 and PP2A. Interacts with SELENON (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P30957, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10830164,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18650434}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P62942:FKBP1A; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-1170425, EBI-1027571;
CC       P68106:FKBP1B; NbExp=5; IntAct=EBI-1170425, EBI-6693977;
CC       Q00987:MDM2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-1170425, EBI-389668;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10830164}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10830164}. Membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:10830164}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305|PubMed:10830164}. Sarcoplasmic reticulum
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P30957}. Note=The number of predicted
CC       transmembrane domains varies between orthologs, but both N-
CC       terminus and C-terminus seem to be cytoplasmic. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q92736-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q92736-2; Sequence=VSP_005953;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in heart muscle (at protein level).
CC       Heart muscle, brain (cerebellum and hippocampus) and placenta.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10830164, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9607712}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed in myometrium during pregnancy.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9148749}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By TGFB1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:9148749}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The calcium release channel activity resides in the C-
CC       terminal region while the remaining part of the protein resides in
CC       the cytoplasm. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- PTM: Channel activity is modulated by phosphorylation.
CC       Phosphorylation at Ser-2808 and Ser-2814 increases the open
CC       probability of the calcium channel. Phosphorylation is increased
CC       in failing heart, leading to calcium leaks and increased
CC       cytoplasmic Ca(2+) levels. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10830164,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20056922}.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation at Ser-2031 by PKA enhances the response to
CC       lumenal calcium. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia, familial, 2
CC       (ARVD2) [MIM:600996]: A congenital heart disease characterized by
CC       infiltration of adipose and fibrous tissue into the right
CC       ventricle and loss of myocardial cells, resulting in ventricular
CC       and supraventricular arrhythmias. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11159936}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Ventricular tachycardia, catecholaminergic polymorphic,
CC       1, with or without atrial dysfunction and/or dilated
CC       cardiomyopathy (CPVT1) [MIM:604772]: An arrhythmogenic disorder
CC       characterized by stress-induced, bidirectional ventricular
CC       tachycardia that may degenerate into cardiac arrest and cause
CC       sudden death. Patients present with recurrent syncope, seizures,
CC       or sudden death after physical activity or emotional stress. CPVT1
CC       inheritance is autosomal dominant. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11157710,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11208676, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12093772,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12106942, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14571276,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15046072, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15046073,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15466642, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15544015,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16188589, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17984046,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24793461, ECO:0000269|PubMed:25372681,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27733687}. Note=The disease is caused by
CC       mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ryanodine receptor (TC 1.A.3.1) family.
CC       RYR2 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=CAH71369.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Erroneous gene model prediction.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAH71393.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Erroneous gene model prediction.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAH73918.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Erroneous gene model prediction.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAI14440.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Erroneous gene model prediction.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAI15350.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Erroneous gene model prediction.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAI15936.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Erroneous gene model prediction.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};
CC       Sequence=CAI22065.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Erroneous gene model prediction.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Receptor for ATP that acts as a ligand-gated ion
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Functional P2XRs are organized as homomeric and
CC       heteromeric trimers. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:

CC         IsoId=Q93086-2; Sequence=VSP_004503, VSP_035587;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q93086-4; Sequence=VSP_035588;
CC         Note=May be produced at very low levels due to a premature stop
CC         codon in the mRNA, leading to nonsense-mediated mRNA decay.;
CC       Name=5;
CC         IsoId=Q93086-5; Sequence=VSP_004503;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed at high levels in brain and immune
CC       system.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the P2X receptor family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND INTERACTION WITH NICOTINIC ACETYLCHOLINE RECEPTOR.
RX   PubMed=20027209; DOI=10.1371/journal.pbio.1000265;
RA   Jospin M., Qi Y.B., Stawicki T.M., Boulin T., Schuske K.R.,
RA   Horvitz H.R., Bessereau J.L., Jorgensen E.M., Jin Y.;
RT   "A neuronal acetylcholine receptor regulates the balance of muscle
RT   excitation and inhibition in Caenorhabditis elegans.";
RL   PLoS Biol. 7:E1000265-E1000265(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Non-alpha subunit of nicotinic acetylcholine receptor
CC       (nAChR) (PubMed:9606719, PubMed:20027209). Probably acts in
CC       cholinergic motoneurons to regulate presynaptic neurotransmitter
CC       release, thereby ensuring normal level of excitation of
CC       cholinergic motoneurons during locomotion (PubMed:20027209).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20027209, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9606719}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of nicotinic acetylcholine receptor. In
CC       cholinergic motoneurons, composed of 2 non-alpha subunits acr-2
CC       and acr-3, and 3 alpha subunits unc-38, unc-63 and acr-12.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20027209, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9606719}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q23022}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q23022}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glutamate-gated chloride channel subunit. Glutamate
CC       binding triggers a rapidly reversible current, while the anti-
CC       helmintic drug ivermectin triggers a permanently open channel
CC       configuration. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11095718,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8702744}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pentamer (By similarity). Homomultimer.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:G5EBR3, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8702744}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC       Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Channels desensitize rapidly in the continued
CC       presence of glutamate and are activated by the glutamate analog
CC       ibotenate. In Xenopus oocytes, avermectins and nodulisporic acid
CC       directly activate channel conductance.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11095718, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8702744}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=12566578; DOI=10.1105/tpc.006999;
RA   Balague C., Lin B., Alcon C., Flottes G., Malmstroem S., Koehler C.,
RA   Neuhaus G., Pelletier G., Gaymard F., Roby D.;
RT   "HLM1, an essential signaling component in the hypersensitive
RT   response, is a member of the cyclic nucleotide-gated channel ion
RT   channel family.";
RL   Plant Cell 15:365-379(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Acts as cyclic nucleotide-gated ion channel. Permeable
CC       to potassium and sodium in a cyclic nucleotide-dependent fashion
CC       (cAMP or cGMP). Might constitute a common downstream component of
CC       the signaling pathways leading to hypersensitive response (HR).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12566578}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer or heterotetramer. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q94AS9-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q94AS9-2; Sequence=VSP_008985, VSP_008986;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Induced by both ethylene and methyl jasmonate
CC       treatments, or after pathogen attack.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The binding of calmodulin to the C-terminus might
CC       interfere with cyclic nucleotide binding and thus channel
CC       activation. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Loss-of-function mutation results in the
CC       loss of the hypersensitive response leading to broad spectrum
CC       disease resistance, and displays a lesion-mimic phenotype.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12566578}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cyclic nucleotide-gated cation channel
CC       (TC 1.A.1.5) family. {ECO:0000305}.

DE   Flags: Precursor;
GN   Name=lgc-46 {ECO:0000312|WormBase:Y71D11A.5};
GN   ORFNames=Y71D11A.5 {ECO:0000312|WormBase:Y71D11A.5};
OS   Caenorhabditis elegans.
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Ecdysozoa; Nematoda; Chromadorea; Rhabditida;
OC   Rhabditoidea; Rhabditidae; Peloderinae; Caenorhabditis.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=6239 {ECO:0000312|Proteomes:UP000001940};
RN   [1] {ECO:0000312|Proteomes:UP000001940}
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE GENOMIC DNA].
RC   STRAIN=Bristol N2 {ECO:0000312|Proteomes:UP000001940};
RX   PubMed=9851916; DOI=10.1126/science.282.5396.2012;
RG   The C. elegans sequencing consortium;
RT   "Genome sequence of the nematode C. elegans: a platform for
RT   investigating biology.";
RL   Science 282:2012-2018(1998).
RN   [2] {ECO:0000305}
RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, DEVELOPMENTAL
RP   STAGE, DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE, AND MUTAGENESIS OF 301-PRO--ALA-302 AND
RP   MET-314.
RX   PubMed=27782882; DOI=10.7554/eLife.21734;
RA   Takayanagi-Kiya S., Zhou K., Jin Y.;
RT   "Release-dependent feedback inhibition by a presynaptically localized
RT   ligand-gated anion channel.";
RL   Elife 5:21734-21749(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Probable component of a ligand-gated anion channel.
CC       Negatively regulates synaptic transmission and synaptic vesicle
CC       release in response to acetylcholine in cholinergic motor neurons.
CC       Role in synaptic vesicle release kinetics may be in association
CC       with the ligand-gated ion channel protein acc-4.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, presynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255}. Cell projection, axon
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}. Cytoplasmic vesicle, secretory
CC       vesicle, synaptic vesicle {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the nervous system, with high
CC       expression in cholinergic motor neurons and weak expression in
CC       GABAergic motor neurons. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expressed in the dorsal nerve cord of L1
CC       larva and on the dorsal side only of L4 larva and adults.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Viable, with normal growth, reproduction and
CC       locomotion. Increased sensitivity to the acetylcholine esterase
CC       inhibitor aldicarb, but normal sensitivity to levamisole, an
CC       agonist for postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors on muscles. In
CC       response to induced acetylcholine release, the amplitude and rise
CC       phase of excitatory postsynaptic currents (eEPSCs) during synaptic
CC       transmission is as wild-type, but there is prolonged and slow
CC       decay of eEPSCs during the late phase of synaptic transmission,
CC       which results in increased release of synaptic vesicles in
CC       cholinergic motor neurons. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: After binding acetylcholine, the AChR responds by an
CC       extensive change in conformation that affects all subunits and
CC       leads to opening of an ion-conducting channel across the plasma
CC       membrane.

CC       delta, and gamma chains.

CC       membrane protein.

RN   [7]
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=23969459; DOI=10.1038/nature12478;
RA   Mousavi S.A., Chauvin A., Pascaud F., Kellenberger S., Farmer E.E.;
RT   "GLUTAMATE RECEPTOR-LIKE genes mediate leaf-to-leaf wound
RT   signalling.";
RL   Nature 500:422-426(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glutamate-gated receptor that probably acts as non-
CC       selective cation channel, at least in roots and hypocotyls. Can be
CC       triggered by Ala, Asn, Cys, Glu, Gly, Ser and glutathione (a
CC       tripeptide consisting of Glu-Gly-Cys). Mediates leaf-to-leaf wound
CC       signaling. May be involved in light-signal transduction and
CC       calcium homeostasis via the regulation of calcium influx into
CC       cells. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17012403, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18162597,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23969459}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: May form heteromers. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed predominantly in roots and siliques.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12082126}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Impaired glutamate-triggered (and Ala, Asn,
CC       Cys, Gly, Ser and glutathione-triggered) membrane depolarization
CC       and calcium rise. Reduced wound-activated surface potential
CC       changes (WASP) duration in the wounded leaf, resulting in a
CC       decreased induction of the regulators of jasmonate-signaling in
CC       the systemic leaves. Glr3.3 and glr3.6 double mutant has no
CC       detectable changes in surface potential in systemic leaves and the
CC       induction of the regulators of jasmonate-signaling is more
CC       strongly decreased. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17012403,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18162597, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23969459}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor (TC 1.A.9.5) subfamily.
CC       GABRA4 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA].
RC   STRAIN=C57BL/6J; TISSUE=Brain;
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: After binding acetylcholine, the AChR responds by an
CC       extensive change in conformation that affects all subunits and
CC       leads to opening of an ion-conducting channel across the plasma
CC       membrane permeable to sodiun ions. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Neuronal AChR is composed of two different types of
CC       subunits: alpha and beta. Beta-2 subunit can be combined to alpha-
CC       2, alpha-3 or alpha-4 to give rise to functional receptors,
CC       complexes with beta-2 may be heteropentamers. Alpha-2/4:beta-2
CC       nAChR complexes are proposed to exist in two subtypes: LS (low
CC       agonist sensitivity) with a (alpha-2/4)3:(beta-2)2 and HS (high
CC       agonist sensitivity) with a (alpha-2/4)2:(beta-2)3 stoichiometry;
CC       the subtypes differ in their subunit binding interfaces which are
CC       involved in ligand binding. Interacts with RIC3; which is required
CC       for proper folding and assembly. Interacts with LYPD6. The
CC       heteropentamer alpha3-beta-2 interacts with alpha-cconotoxins
CC       BuIA, MII, ImI, ImII, PnIA and GID (By similarity). The
CC       heteropentamer alpha-4-beta-2 interacts with the alpha-conotoxins
CC       PnIA, GID and MII (By similarity). {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P12390, ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P17787}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily. Beta-
CC       2/CHRNB2 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium channel mediating constitutive calcium ion
CC       entry. Its activity is increased by reduction in extracellular
CC       osmolarity, by store depletion and muscarinic receptor activation.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12672799, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12672827}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12672827};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12672827}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:

CC       Name=2; Synonyms=TRPM3a;
CC         IsoId=Q9HCF6-2; Sequence=VSP_012826;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=TRPM3b;
CC         IsoId=Q9HCF6-3; Sequence=VSP_012826, VSP_012828;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=TRPM3d;
CC         IsoId=Q9HCF6-4; Sequence=VSP_012826, VSP_012829;

CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed primarily in the kidney and, at
CC       lower levels, in brain, testis, ovary, pancreas and spinal cord.
CC       Expression in the brain and kidney was determined at protein
CC       level. In the kidney, expressed predominantly in the collecting
CC       tubular epithelium in the medulla, medullary rays, and
CC       periglomerular regions; in the brain, highest levels are found in
CC       the cerebellum, choroid plexus, the locus coeruleus, the posterior
CC       thalamus and the substantia nigra. Down-regulated in renal tumors
CC       compared to normal kidney. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12672799,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12672827}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       LTrpC subfamily. TRPM3 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RC   STRAIN=Sprague-Dawley;
RX   PubMed=10854267; DOI=10.1046/j.1471-4159.2000.0750240.x;
RA   Hanna M.C., Davies P.A., Hales T.G., Kirkness E.F.;
RT   "Evidence for expression of heteromeric serotonin 5-HT(3) receptors in
RT   rodents.";
RL   J. Neurochem. 75:240-247(2000).
RN   [2]
RP   SUBUNIT, AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=12151552;

RT   "Differential composition of 5-hydroxytryptamine3 receptors
RT   synthesized in the rat CNS and peripheral nervous system.";

RN   [3]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=12867984; DOI=10.1038/nature01788;
RA   Kelley S.P., Dunlop J.I., Kirkness E.F., Lambert J.J., Peters J.A.;
RT   "A cytoplasmic region determines single-channel conductance in 5-HT3
RT   receptors.";
RL   Nature 424:321-324(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: This is one of the several different receptors for 5-
CC       hydroxytryptamine (serotonin), a biogenic hormone that functions
CC       as a neurotransmitter, a hormone, and a mitogen. This receptor is
CC       a ligand-gated ion channel, which when activated causes fast,
CC       depolarizing responses. It is a cation-specific, but otherwise
CC       relatively nonselective, ion channel.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12867984}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms pentahomomeric complex as well as pentaheteromeric
CC       complex with HTR3B; homomeric complex is functional but exhibits
CC       low conductance with modified voltage dependence and antagonist
CC       affinity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10854267,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12151552}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC       Note=Presumably retained within the endoplasmic reticulum unless
CC       complexed with HTR3A. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in peripheral neurons, but not in
CC       neurons of the central nervous system.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12151552}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By nerve growth factor in PC12 cells.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10854267}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylation is required for membrane localization.
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. 5-hydroxytryptamine receptor (TC 1.A.9.2) subfamily. HTR3B
CC       sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=17522321; DOI=10.1523/JNEUROSCI.4973-06.2007;
RA   Zhang Z., Zhao Z., Margolskee R., Liman E.;

RN   [16] {ECO:0000305}
RP   FUNCTION, AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=17267604; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0610201104;
RA   Lin W., Margolskee R., Donnert G., Hell S.W., Restrepo D.;
RT   "Olfactory neurons expressing transient receptor potential channel M5
RT   (TRPM5) are involved in sensing semiochemicals.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 104:2471-2476(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Voltage-modulated Ca(2+)-activated, monovalent cation
CC       channel (VCAM) that mediates a transient membrane depolarization
CC       and plays a central role in taste transduction. Monovalent-
CC       specific, non-selective cation channel that mediates the transport
CC       of Na(+), K(+) and Cs(+) ions equally well. Activated directly by
CC       increases in intracellular Ca(2+), but is impermeable to it.
CC       Gating is voltage-dependent and displays rapid activation and
CC       deactivation kinetics upon channel stimulation even during
CC       sustained elevations in Ca(2+). Also activated by a fast
CC       intracellular Ca(2+) increase in response to inositol 1,4,5-
CC       triphosphate-producing receptor agonists. The channel is blocked
CC       by extracellular acidification. External acidification has 2
CC       effects, a fast reversible block of the current and a slower
CC       irreversible enhancement of current inactivation. Is a highly
CC       temperature-sensitive, heat activated channel showing a steep
CC       increase of inward currents at temperatures between 15 and 35
CC       degrees Celsius. Heat activation is due to a shift of the voltage-
CC       dependent activation curve to negative potentials. Activated by
CC       arachidonic acid in vitro. May be involved in perception of
CC       bitter, sweet and umami tastes. May also be involved in sensing
CC       semiochemicals. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12842017,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14657398, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15731110,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16355226, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16436689,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16935556, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17267604,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17522321}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) is
CC       able to partially restore sensitivity to Ca(2+) after
CC       desensitization. Inhibited by flufenamic acid with an IC(50) of
CC       24.5 uM and spermine with an IC(50) of 37 uM.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:14657398, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15670874}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000255}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q8TD43, ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1 {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10903843, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10907850,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10915772, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12842017,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15489334, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16141072};
CC         IsoId=Q9JJH7-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2 {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10915772};
CC         IsoId=Q9JJH7-2; Sequence=VSP_052746, VSP_052747;
CC       Name=3 {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12842017};
CC         IsoId=Q9JJH7-3; Sequence=VSP_052744, VSP_052745;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Strongly expressed in liver, heart, testis,
CC       brain and kidney. Detected in fetal liver, kidney, spleen, brain,
CC       heart and lung, and in adult skin, eyes, spleen, stomach, small
CC       intestine, colon, lung, bladder, pancreas and thymus.
CC       Biallelically expressed at all stages and tissues examined. Also
CC       expressed in subsets of taste receptor cells of the tongue, in
CC       olfactory sensory neurons of the main olfactory epithelium and in
CC       the vomeronasal organ. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10903843,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12368808, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17267604,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17610722}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Mice show diminished behavioral and nerve
CC       responses to bitter, sweet and umami tastes.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16436689}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the transient receptor (TC 1.A.4) family.
CC       LTrpC subfamily. TRPM5 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=10662822;
RA   Gerstner A., Zong X., Hofmann F., Biel M.;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Visual signal transduction is mediated by a G-protein
CC       coupled cascade using cGMP as second messenger. This protein can
CC       be activated by cyclic GMP which leads to an opening of the cation
CC       channel and thereby causing a depolarization of cone
CC       photoreceptors. Essential for the generation of light-evoked
CC       electrical responses in the red-, green- and blue sensitive cones
CC       (By similarity). Induced a flickering channel gating, weakened the
CC       outward rectification in the presence of extracellular calcium,
CC       increased sensitivity for L-cis diltiazem and enhanced the cAMP
CC       efficacy of the channel when coexpressed with CNGB3. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10662822}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Tetramer formed of three CNGA3 and one CNGB3 modulatory
CC       subunits. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Prominently expressed in retina.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The C-terminal coiled-coil domain mediates
CC       homotrimerization of CNGA subunits. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cyclic nucleotide-gated cation channel
CC       (TC 1.A.1.5) family. CNGA3 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Craniata; Vertebrata; Euteleostomi;

OX   NCBI_TaxID=10090;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], FUNCTION, SUBUNIT, AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RC   STRAIN=C57BL/6J; TISSUE=Retina;
RX   PubMed=10662822;
RA   Gerstner A., Zong X., Hofmann F., Biel M.;

RT   cyclic nucleotide-gated channel subunit from mouse retina.";
RL   J. Neurosci. 20:1324-1332(2000).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Visual signal transduction is mediated by a G-protein
CC       coupled cascade using cGMP as second messenger. This protein can
CC       be activated by cGMP which leads to an opening of the cation
CC       channel and thereby causing a depolarization of rod
CC       photoreceptors. Essential for the generation of light-evoked
CC       electrical responses in the red-, green- and blue sensitive cones
CC       (By similarity). Induced a flickering channel gating, weakened the
CC       outward rectification in the presence of extracellular calcium,
CC       increased sensitivity for L-cis diltiazem and enhanced the cAMP
CC       efficacy of the channel when coexpressed with CNGA3. {ECO:0000250,

CC       subunits. {ECO:0000250}.

CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Small subset of retinal photorecptor cells and
CC       testis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10662822}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cyclic nucleotide-gated cation channel
CC       (TC 1.A.1.5) family. CNGB3 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

ID   HCN1_RAT                Reviewed;         910 AA.
AC   Q9JKB0;
DT   28-FEB-2003, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.
DT   01-OCT-2000, sequence version 1.
DT   22-NOV-2017, entry version 118.
DE   RecName: Full=Potassium/sodium hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated channel 1;
GN   Name=Hcn1;
OS   Rattus norvegicus (Rat).
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Craniata; Vertebrata; Euteleostomi;
OC   Mammalia; Eutheria; Euarchontoglires; Glires; Rodentia; Myomorpha;
OC   Muroidea; Muridae; Murinae; Rattus.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=10116;
RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RC   STRAIN=Sprague-Dawley; TISSUE=Brain;
RX   PubMed=11000485; DOI=10.1016/S0169-328X(00)00155-8;
RA   Monteggia L.M., Eisch A.J., Tang M.D., Kaczmarek L.K., Nestler E.J.;
RT   "Cloning and localization of the hyperpolarization-activated cyclic
RT   nucleotide-gated channel family in rat brain.";
RL   Brain Res. Mol. Brain Res. 81:129-139(2000).
RN   [2]
RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=11675786; DOI=10.1038/35098087;
RA   Stevens D.R., Seifert R., Bufe B., Mueller F., Kremmer E., Gauss R.,
RA   Meyerhof W., Kaupp U.B., Lindemann B.;
RT   "Hyperpolarization-activated channels HCN1 and HCN4 mediate responses
RT   to sour stimuli.";
RL   Nature 413:631-635(2001).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Hyperpolarization-activated ion channel exhibiting weak
CC       selectivity for potassium over sodium ions. Contributes to the
CC       native pacemaker currents in heart (If) and in neurons (Ih). May
CC       mediate responses to sour stimuli. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11675786}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Activated by cAMP, and at 10-100 times higher
CC       concentrations, also by cGMP. cAMP binding promotes
CC       tetramerization and formation of an active channel. Compared to
CC       other family members, cAMP has less stimulatory effect on HCN1
CC       because part of the molecules already contain bound cAMP and form
CC       homotetramers when cAMP levels are low (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. Heterotetramer with HCN2. The potassium
CC       channel is composed of a homo- or heterotetrameric complex of
CC       pore-forming subunits. Interacts with KCNE2. Interacts with the
CC       SH3 domain of CSK. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O88704}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11675786};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11675786}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in cerebral cortex,
CC       cerebellum, throughout the hippocampus, in medial habenula,
CC       anterior dorsal nucleus in the thalamus, tenia tecta, several
CC       nuclei of the general motor system and in optic nerve layer.
CC       Detected in a subset of elongated cells in taste buds.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11000485, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11675786}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O60741}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel HCN family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------
CC   Copyrighted by the UniProt Consortium, see http://www.uniprot.org/terms
CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RP   MUTAGENESIS OF GLU-221 AND PRO-224, AND SUBUNIT.

RA   Azam L., Papakyriakou A., Zouridakis M., Giastas P., Tzartos S.J.,
