RN   [8]
RP   ERRATUM.
RX   PubMed=27559150; DOI=10.1124/mol.114.096511err;
RA   Azam L., Papakyriakou A., Zouridakis M., Giastas P., Tzartos S.J.,
RA   McIntosh J.M.;
RT   "Corrections to 'Molecular interaction of alpha-conotoxin RgIA with
RT   the rat alpha9alpha10 nicotinic acetylcholine receptor'.";
RL   Mol. Pharmacol. 90:415-417(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ionotropic receptor with a probable role in the
CC       modulation of auditory stimuli. Agonist binding may induce an
CC       extensive change in conformation that affects all subunits and
CC       leads to opening of an ion-conducting channel across the plasma
CC       membrane. The channel is permeable to a range of divalent cations
CC       including calcium, the influx of which may activate a potassium
CC       current which hyperpolarizes the cell membrane. In the ear, this
CC       leads to a reduction in basilar membrane motion, altering the
CC       activity of auditory nerve fibers and reducing the range of
CC       dynamic hearing. This may protect against acoustic trauma.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11248107, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12117536,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:14742688}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms heterooligomeric channels in conjunction with
CC       CHRNA9. The native outer hair cell receptor may be composed of
CC       CHRNA9-CHRNA10 heterooligomers. Interacts with the conotoxin GeXXA
CC       (PubMed:26395518). Interacts with the alpha-conotoxin RgIA
CC       (PubMed:25740413). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25740413,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26395518}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC       Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the outer hair cells of the
CC       cochlea and the neurons of dorsal root ganglia.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11248107, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12401316}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expression in the inner hair cells of the ear
CC       is lost at the onset of hearing, around P12. This correlates with
CC       a loss of sensitivity of these cells to cholinergic stimuli.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11248107, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15356192}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The heterooligomeric receptor composed of CHRNA9
CC       and CHRNA10 has an atypical pharmacological profile, binding
CC       several non-nicotinic ligands including strychnine (a glycine
CC       receptor antagonist) and atropine (a muscarinic acetylcholine
CC       receptor antagonist).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily. Alpha-
CC       10/CHRNA10 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [7]
RP   FUNCTION, MUTAGENESIS OF ARG-491 AND ARG-578, AND DOMAIN.
RX   PubMed=26929345; DOI=10.1073/pnas.1524629113;
RA   Gao Q.F., Gu L.L., Wang H.Q., Fei C.F., Fang X., Hussain J., Sun S.J.,
RA   Dong J.Y., Liu H., Wang Y.F.;
RT   "Cyclic nucleotide-gated channel 18 is an essential Ca2+ channel in
RT   pollen tube tips for pollen tube guidance to ovules in Arabidopsis.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 113:3096-3101(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cyclic nucleotide-gated ion channel required for
CC       directional pollen tube growth into the transmitting tract
CC       (PubMed:17726111, PubMed:26929345). Acts as a Ca(2+)-permeable
CC       divalent cation-selective channel inhibited by either lanthanum or
CC       gadolinium (PubMed:24380879). Regulated by CPK32 to mediate Ca(2+)
CC       transport across the plasma membrane in response to Ca(2+)
CC       oscillation (PubMed:24121288). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17726111,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24121288, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24380879,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:26929345}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homomultimer (PubMed:24380879). Interacts with CPK32
CC       (PubMed:24121288). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24121288,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24380879}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17726111,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24121288}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305}. Cytoplasmic vesicle membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17726111}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000305}. Note=focused at the cell perimeter of the growing
CC       pollen tube tip. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17726111,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24121288}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in pollen grains. Not detected in
CC       leaves, roots or root hairs. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17726111}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The transmembrane domains are indispensable for pollen
CC       tube guidance. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26929345}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The binding of calmodulin to the C-terminus might
CC       interfere with cyclic nucleotide binding and thus channel
CC       activation. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Male sterility.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:17726111}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cyclic nucleotide-gated cation channel
CC       (TC 1.A.1.5) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=12082126; DOI=10.1093/oxfordjournals.molbev.a004165;
RA   Chiu J.C., Brenner E.D., DeSalle R., Nitabach M.N., Holmes T.C.,
RA   Coruzzi G.M.;
RT   "Phylogenetic and expression analysis of the glutamate-receptor-like
RT   gene family in Arabidopsis thaliana.";
RL   Mol. Biol. Evol. 19:1066-1082(2002).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glutamate-gated receptor that probably acts as non-
CC       selective cation channel. May be involved in light-signal
CC       transduction and calcium homeostasis via the regulation of calcium
CC       influx into cells.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: May form heteromers. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed predominantly in roots.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12082126}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION.

RA   Kang J., Turano F.J.;
RT   "The putative glutamate receptor 1.1 (AtGLR1.1) functions as a

RN   [8]
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=15564521; DOI=10.1093/pcp/pch159;
RA   Kang J., Mehta S., Turano F.J.;
RT   "The putative glutamate receptor 1.1 (AtGLR1.1) in Arabidopsis
RT   thaliana regulates abscisic acid biosynthesis and signaling to control
RT   development and water loss.";
RL   Plant Cell Physiol. 45:1380-1389(2004).
RN   [9]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=18625242; DOI=10.1016/j.jmb.2008.06.076;
RA   Tapken D., Hollmann M.;
RT   "Arabidopsis thaliana glutamate receptor ion channel function
RT   demonstrated by ion pore transplantation.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 383:36-48(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glutamate-gated receptor that probably acts as non-
CC       selective cation channel. Can transport sodium, potassium, and
CC       calcium ions. Functions as a carbon and nitrogen regulator and/or
CC       sensor that regulates carbon and nitrogen metabolism and distinct
CC       physiological process such as germination through the control of
CC       acid abscisic (ABA) biosynthesis. May be involved in light-signal
CC       transduction and calcium homeostasis via the regulation of calcium
CC       influx into cells. Seems required for the regulation of the
CC       abscisic acid (ABA) signaling pathway that modulates many aspects
CC       of plant physiology such as seed germination and response to
CC       drought (e.g. stomata opening). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12738881,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15564521, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18625242}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: May form heteromers. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed predominantly in roots. First
CC       detected in the root-shoot junction, and later in lateral roots
CC       and at the margin of matures leaves.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12082126}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Increased sensitivity to exogenous abscisic
CC       acid (ABA) and higher ABA levels in leaves.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15564521}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=10400919; DOI=10.1161/01.RES.85.1.e1;
RA   Shi W., Wymore R., Yu H., Wu J., Wymore R.T., Pan Z., Robinson R.B.,
RA   Dixon J.E., McKinnon D., Cohen I.S.;
RT   "Distribution and prevalence of hyperpolarization-activated cation
RT   channel (HCN) mRNA expression in cardiac tissues.";
RL   Circ. Res. 85:1-6(1999).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Hyperpolarization-activated ion channel exhibiting weak
CC       selectivity for potassium over sodium ions. Contributes to the
CC       native pacemaker currents in heart (If) and in neurons (Ih). May
CC       mediate responses to sour stimuli. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11328811}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Activated by cAMP, and at 10-100 times higher
CC       concentrations, also by cGMP. cAMP binding promotes
CC       tetramerization and formation of an active channel. Compared to
CC       other family members, cAMP has less stimulatory effect on HCN1
CC       because part of the molecules already contain bound cAMP and form
CC       homotetramers when cAMP levels are low.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11328811}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. Heterotetramer with HCN2. The potassium
CC       channel is composed of a homo- or heterotetrameric complex of
CC       pore-forming subunits. Interacts with KCNE2. Interacts with the
CC       SH3 domain of CSK. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O88704}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11328811};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11328811}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in myocytes in heart sinoatrial node
CC       (SAN) and in brain, in particular in the granule cell layer and in
CC       Purkinje neuron bodies in the cerebellum.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10400919, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11328811}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O60741}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel HCN family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- CAUTION: It is uncertain whether Met-1 or Met-30 is the initiator.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RP   FUNCTION, AND INTERACTION WITH NICOTINIC ACETYLCHOLINE RECEPTOR.
RX   PubMed=20027209; DOI=10.1371/journal.pbio.1000265;
RA   Jospin M., Qi Y.B., Stawicki T.M., Boulin T., Schuske K.R.,

RN   [6]
RP   INTERACTION WITH LEV-10.
RX   PubMed=21252855; DOI=10.1038/emboj.2010.355;
RA   Rapti G., Richmond J., Bessereau J.L.;
RT   "A single immunoglobulin-domain protein required for clustering
RT   acetylcholine receptors in C. elegans.";
RL   EMBO J. 30:706-718(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Alpha subunit of nicotinic acetylcholine receptor
CC       (nAChR) (PubMed:15280391, PubMed:15990870, PubMed:20027209).
CC       Probably acts in cholinergic motoneurons to regulate presynaptic
CC       neurotransmitter release, thereby ensuring normal level of
CC       excitation of cholinergic motoneurons during locomotion
CC       (PubMed:20027209). Involved in nAChR sensitivity to nicotine and
CC       levamisole (PubMed:15280391, PubMed:15990870).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15280391, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990870,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20027209}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Component of nicotinic acetylcholine receptor
CC       (PubMed:15990870, PubMed:20027209). In muscles, composed of 2 non-
CC       alpha subunits lev-1 and unc-29, and 3 alpha subunits unc-38, unc-
CC       63 and lev-8 (PubMed:15990870). In cholinergic motoneurons,
CC       composed of 2 non-alpha subunits acr-2 and acr-3, and 3 alpha
CC       subunits unc-38, unc-63 and acr-12 (PubMed:20027209). Interacts
CC       with lev-10 (PubMed:21252855). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990870,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20027209, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21252855}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q27218}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q27218}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in body wall muscles, in vulval
CC       muscles and in neurons. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15280391}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: RNAi-mediated knockdown causes a resistance
CC       to nicotine-mediated paralysis. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15990870}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=19133302; DOI=10.1016/j.bbamcr.2008.12.005;
RA   Giusti C., Tresse E., Luciani M.-F., Golstein P.;
RT   "Autophagic cell death: Analysis in Dictyostelium.";
RL   Biochim. Biophys. Acta 1793:1422-1431(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: May be a receptor for inositol 1,4,5 trisphosphate which
CC       governs calcium fluxes from the endoplasmic reticulum stores into
CC       the cytosol. May be involved in autophagic cell death.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10970875, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12211100,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15760480, ECO:0000269|PubMed:17077123,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17854889, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18077554,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18196962, ECO:0000269|PubMed:19133302}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Expression is low during growth and rises to
CC       a peak at 9 hours of development when chemotactic aggregation to
CC       cyclic AMP is near its height; levels then decrease through the
CC       end of development. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10970875}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Null cells show abolition of calcium entry
CC       in response to chemoattractant, response to cyclic AMP and normal
CC       increase in free cytosolic calcium that follows chemotactic
CC       stimulation. Cells show formation of smaller fruiting bodies and
CC       abolition of autophagic cell death. Cells show absence of
CC       vacuolization. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10970875,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12211100, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15760480,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:17077123, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18077554,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18196962, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18486207,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19133302}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the InsP3 receptor family. {ECO:0000305}.

RX   PubMed=15712225; DOI=10.1002/humu.20142;
RA   Nishiguchi K.M., Sandberg M.A., Gorji N., Berson E.L., Dryja T.P.;
RT   "Cone cGMP-gated channel mutations and clinical findings in patients
RT   with achromatopsia, macular degeneration, and other hereditary cone
RT   diseases.";
RL   Hum. Mutat. 25:248-258(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Visual signal transduction is mediated by a G-protein
CC       coupled cascade using cGMP as second messenger. This protein can
CC       be activated by cGMP which leads to an opening of the cation
CC       channel and thereby causing a depolarization of rod
CC       photoreceptors. Induced a flickering channel gating, weakened the
CC       outward rectification in the presence of extracellular calcium,
CC       increased sensitivity for L-cis diltiazem and enhanced the cAMP
CC       efficiency of the channel when coexpressed with CNGA3 (By
CC       similarity). Essential for the generation of light-evoked
CC       electrical responses in the red-, green- and blue sensitive cones.
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10888875}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Tetramer formed of three CNGA3 and one CNGB3 modulatory
CC       subunits. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10888875,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:21878911}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q9NQW8-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=Q9NQW8-2; Sequence=VSP_009742;
CC         Note=No experimental confirmation available.;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed specifically in the retina.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10958649}.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Stargardt disease 1 (STGD1) [MIM:248200]: A common
CC       hereditary macular degeneration. It is characterized by decreased
CC       central vision, atrophy of the macula and underlying retinal
CC       pigment epithelium, and frequent presence of prominent flecks in
CC       the posterior pole of the retina. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15712225}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Achromatopsia 3 (ACHM3) [MIM:262300]: An ocular
CC       stationary disorder due to the absence of functioning cone
CC       photoreceptors in the retina. It is characterized by total
CC       colorblindness, low visual acuity, photophobia and nystagmus.
CC       Achromatopsia type 3 patients manifest severe myopia.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10888875, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10958649,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12357335, ECO:0000269|PubMed:14757870,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15657609, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15712225}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cyclic nucleotide-gated cation channel
CC       (TC 1.A.1.5) family. CNGB3 subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAF80179.1; Type=Erroneous initiation; Note=Translation N-terminally extended.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
RN   [5]
RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, AND ENZYME
RP   REGULATION.
RX   PubMed=16043489; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M502508200;
RA   Stieber J., Stockl G., Herrmann S., Hassfurth B., Hofmann F.;
RT   "Functional expression of the human HCN3 channel.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 280:34635-34643(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Hyperpolarization-activated potassium channel. May also
CC       facilitate the permeation of sodium ions.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16043489}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Inhibited by Cs(1+) and ZD7288. Is apparently
CC       not activated by cAMP. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16043489}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. The potassium channel is probably composed
CC       of a homo- or heterotetrameric complex of pore-forming subunits.
CC       Interacts with KCTD3 and PEX5L. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:O88705,
CC       ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q9UL51}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q4ACU6-1:Shank3 (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-11178054, EBI-16201983;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16043489};
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16043489}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in brain.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16043489}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel HCN family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAH28024.2; Type=Erroneous initiation; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   CHARACTERIZATION, ALTERNATIVE SPLICING (ISOFORMS 1 AND 2), AND
RP   IDENTIFICATION IN A COMPLEX WITH GRIN1; GRIN2A OR GRIN2B.
RX   PubMed=11929923; DOI=10.1152/jn.00531.2001;
RA   Sasaki Y.F., Rothe T., Premkumar L.S., Das S., Cui J., Talantova M.V.,
RA   Wong H.-K., Gong X., Chan S.F., Zhang D., Nakanishi N., Sucher N.J.,
RA   Lipton S.A.;
RT   "Characterization and comparison of the NR3A subunit of the NMDA
RT   receptor in recombinant systems and primary cortical neurons.";
RL   J. Neurophysiol. 87:2052-2063(2002).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: NMDA receptor subtype of glutamate-gated ion channels
CC       with reduced single-channel conductance, low calcium permeability
CC       and low voltage-dependent sensitivity to magnesium. Mediated by
CC       glycine. May play a role in the development of dendritic spines.
CC       May also play a role in PPP2CB-NMDAR mediated signaling mechanism.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms heteromeric channel of a zeta subunit (GRIN1), a
CC       epsilon subunit (GRIN2A, GRIN2B, GRIN2C or GRIN2D) and a third
CC       subunit (GRIN3A or GRIN3B). Does not form functional homomeric
CC       channels. Found in a complex with GRIN1, GRIN2A or GRIN2B and
CC       PPP2CB. Probably interacts with PPP2CB. No complex with PPP2CB is
CC       detected when NMDARs are stimulated by NMDA.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11160393, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11588171,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11929923, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12391275}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC       Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell membrane. Cell junction,
CC       synapse, postsynaptic cell membrane, postsynaptic density.
CC       Note=Enriched in postsynaptic plasma membrane and postsynaptic
CC       densities. Requires the presence of GRIN1 to be targeted at the
CC       plasma membrane.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=NR3-long, NR3-l, NR3A-2;
CC         IsoId=Q9R1M7-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=NR3-short, NR3-s;
CC         IsoId=Q9R1M7-2; Sequence=VSP_011512;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Isoform 1 and isoform 2 are expressed in
CC       olfactory bulb, frontal occipital, entorhinal and pyriform
CC       cortices, hippocampus, striatum, thalamus, cerebellum and spinal
CC       cord. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7472412, ECO:0000269|PubMed:7472413,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9891978}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Isoform 1 and isoform 2 are expressed in
CC       spinal cord, medulla, pons, tegmentum, thalamus and hypothalamus
CC       at 15 dpc onwards. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7472412,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:7472413, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9891978}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11160393}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. NR3A/GRIN3A subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glutamate-gated receptor that probably acts as non-
CC       selective cation channel. May be involved in light-signal
CC       transduction and calcium homeostasis via the regulation of calcium
CC       influx into cells.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: May form heteromers. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed predominantly in leaves and
CC       siliques. Also detected in roots. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12082126}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Glutamate-gated receptor that probably acts as non-
CC       selective cation channel. May be involved in light-signal
CC       transduction and calcium homeostasis via the regulation of calcium
CC       influx into cells.

CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed predominantly in roots.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12082126}.

CC       1.A.10.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   INTERACTION WITH SELENON, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=18713863; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0806015105;
RA   Jurynec M.J., Xia R., Mackrill J.J., Gunther D., Crawford T.,
RA   Flanigan K.M., Abramson J.J., Howard M.T., Grunwald D.J.;
RT   "Selenoprotein N is required for ryanodine receptor calcium release
RT   channel activity in human and zebrafish muscle.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 105:12485-12490(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Calcium channel that mediates the release of Ca(2+) from
CC       the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm in muscle and
CC       thereby plays a role in triggering muscle contraction. May
CC       regulate Ca(2+) release by other calcium channels. Calcium channel
CC       that mediates Ca(2+)-induced Ca(2+) release from the endoplasmic
CC       reticulum in non-muscle cells. Plays a role in cellular calcium
CC       signaling. Contributes to cellular calcium ion homeostasis.
CC       Isoform 2 lacks a predicted transmembrane segment and does not
CC       form functional calcium channels by itself; however, it can form
CC       tetramers with isoforms that contain the full complement of
CC       transmembrane segments and modulate their activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10358090, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12213830,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12471029, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16274254,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9305876, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9614063}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. Isoform 2 can form tetramers with isoform
CC       1. Heterotetramer with RYR2. Interacts with FKBP1A. Interacts with
CC       CALM. Interacts with SELENON (PubMed:18713863).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10358090, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12213830,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12471029, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16274254,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:18713863, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9614063}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-9542578, EBI-9542578;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Sarcoplasmic reticulum membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein. Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Microsome
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Sarcoplasmic reticulum
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:18713863}. Note=The number of predicted
CC       transmembrane domains varies between orthologs, but both N-
CC       terminus and C-terminus seem to be cytoplasmic. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=4;
CC         Comment=Additional isoforms seem to exist.;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=Q9TS33-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=AS-8a;
CC         IsoId=Q9TS33-2; Sequence=VSP_042306;
CC         Note=Lacks a predicted transmembrane segment and does not form
CC         functional calcium channels.;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=Q9TS33-3; Sequence=VSP_042305;
CC       Name=4;
CC         IsoId=Q9TS33-4; Sequence=VSP_042307;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in skeletal muscle from young rabbits
CC       and in adult diaphragm muscle (at protein level). Detected in
CC       brain, especially in corpus striatum, thalamus and hippocampus.
CC       Detected in taenia coli, uterus, vas deferens, aorta, stomach,
CC       small intestine, heart, diaphragm and ureter. Isoform 2 is highly
CC       expressed in uterus and aorta, and at much lower levels in heart,
CC       brain and diaphragm. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10358090,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:12471029, ECO:0000269|PubMed:1330694,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16176801, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16274254,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9305876}.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: Ubiquitous in skeletal muscle in neonates and
CC       in 15 day old rabbits. In adult, detected in diaphragm muscle, and
CC       in a subset of skeletal muscles including digastricus,
CC       pterygoideus, tongue and masseter. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16176801}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The calcium release channel activity resides in the C-
CC       terminal region while the remaining part of the protein resides in
CC       the cytoplasm. {ECO:0000305|PubMed:10358090}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Channel activity is modulated by the alkaloid
CC       ryanodine that binds to the open calcium-release channel with high
CC       affinity. At low concentrations, ryanodine maintains the channel
CC       in an open conformation. High ryanodine concentrations inhibit
CC       channel activity. Channel activity is regulated by calmodulin
CC       (CALM). The calcium release is activated by elevated cytoplasmic
CC       calcium levels in the micromolar range, by caffeine and adenine
CC       nucleotides, such as AMP and ATP. Inhibited by Mg(2+) and
CC       ruthenium red.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ryanodine receptor (TC 1.A.3.1) family.

RT   MC in Caenorhabditis elegans.";

RX   PubMed=9789046; DOI=10.1073/pnas.95.22.13091;
RA   Lakowski B., Hekimi S.;
RT   "The genetics of caloric restriction in Caenorhabditis elegans.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 95:13091-13096(1998).
RN   [6] {ECO:0000305}
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=15141086; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0400848101;
RA   Huang C., Xiong C., Kornfeld K.;
RT   "Measurements of age-related changes of physiological processes that
RT   predict lifespan of Caenorhabditis elegans.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 101:8084-8089(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: After binding acetylcholine, the AChR responds by an
CC       extensive change in conformation that affects all subunits and
CC       leads to opening of an ion-conducting channel across the plasma
CC       membrane (By similarity). Nicotinic acetylcholine receptor in the
CC       MC pharyngeal motor neuron involved in pharyngeal pumping. Has a
CC       role in the determination of life span possibly via calorific
CC       restriction which affects growth rate, although this is
CC       independent of metabolic activity. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P22770,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15020415, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15141086,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:8462849, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8601480,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9789046}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Neuronal AChR seems to be composed of two different type
CC       of subunits: alpha and beta. {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P22770}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15020415}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15020415}. Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15020415}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15020415}. Note=MC motor neuron.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15020415}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in pharyngeal muscle.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15020415}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Worms exhibit a lack of MC neurotransmission
CC       possibly explaining the observed reduction in pharyngeal pumping
CC       rate. Mutants show differences in their pharyngeal responses to
CC       nicotine. A variety of mutants show an increase in life span
CC       ranging from 29-57% longer than wild-type, extended self-fertile
CC       reproductive span, fast body movement, and a longer pharyngeal
CC       pumping span. The strongest allele (ad1113) shows retarded growth.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15020415, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15141086}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

AC   Q9U358;
DT   22-NOV-2017, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.
DT   01-MAY-2000, sequence version 1.
DT   22-NOV-2017, entry version 125.
DE   RecName: Full=Acetylcholine-gated ion channel acc-4 {ECO:0000305};
DE   Flags: Precursor;
GN   Name=acc-4 {ECO:0000303|PubMed:15579462,
GN   ECO:0000312|WormBase:T27E9.9};
GN   ORFNames=T27E9.9 {ECO:0000312|WormBase:T27E9.9};
OS   Caenorhabditis elegans.
OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Ecdysozoa; Nematoda; Chromadorea; Rhabditida;
OC   Rhabditoidea; Rhabditidae; Peloderinae; Caenorhabditis.
OX   NCBI_TaxID=6239 {ECO:0000312|Proteomes:UP000001940};
RN   [1] {ECO:0000305}
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], FUNCTION, AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=15579462; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M412644200;
RA   Putrenko I., Zakikhani M., Dent J.A.;
RT   "A family of acetylcholine-gated chloride channel subunits in
RT   Caenorhabditis elegans.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 280:6392-6398(2005).
RN   [2] {ECO:0000312|Proteomes:UP000001940}
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE GENOMIC DNA].
RC   STRAIN=Bristol N2 {ECO:0000312|Proteomes:UP000001940};
RX   PubMed=9851916; DOI=10.1126/science.282.5396.2012;

RT   investigating biology.";
RL   Science 282:2012-2018(1998).
RN   [3] {ECO:0000305}
RP   TISSUE SPECIFICITY.
RX   PubMed=26705699; DOI=10.7554/eLife.12432;
RA   Pereira L., Kratsios P., Serrano-Saiz E., Sheftel H., Mayo A.E.,
RA   Hall D.H., White J.G., LeBoeuf B., Garcia L.R., Alon U., Hobert O.;
RT   "A cellular and regulatory map of the cholinergic nervous system of C.
RT   elegans.";
RL   Elife 4:12432-12477(2015).
RN   [4] {ECO:0000305}
RP   FUNCTION, SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=27782882; DOI=10.7554/eLife.21734;
RA   Takayanagi-Kiya S., Zhou K., Jin Y.;
RT   "Release-dependent feedback inhibition by a presynaptically localized
RT   ligand-gated anion channel.";
RL   Elife 5:21734-21749(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Probable acetylcholine-gated chloride channel subunit
CC       (PubMed:15579462). Does not have ion channel activity alone as a
CC       homopentamer, but forms a functional heteropentameric ion channel
CC       with acc-1 (PubMed:15579462). May function with lgc-46 to regulate
CC       synaptic transmission and synaptic vesicle release in response to
CC       acetylcholine in cholinergic motor neurons (PubMed:27782882).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Does not form a functional homopentameric ion channel.
CC       Forms a functional heteropentameric ion channel composed of acc-1
CC       and acc-4. May interact with acc-2; the interaction does not
CC       result in significant heteropentameric ion channel activity.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15579462}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, presynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000255}. Cell projection, axon
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in all cholinergic motor neurons
CC       except for ASJ and RIB neurons. Also expressed in AVF neurons.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:26705699}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Grossly normal movement. In addition, in
CC       response to induced acetylcholine release, there is prolonged and
CC       slow decay of excitory postsynaptic currents which results in
CC       increased release of synaptic vesicles during that late phase of
CC       synaptic vesicle release in cholinergic motor neurons. Knockout in
CC       an lgc-46 gain of function mutant background suppresses the slow
CC       locomotion defect in the single lgc-46 gain of function mutant.
CC       Knockout together with gain of function mutations in lgc-46 and
CC       acr-2 suppresses the convulsion defects in the double lgc-46 and
CC       acr-2 double gain of function mutant.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27782882}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [8]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.71 ANGSTROMS) OF 26-237, FUNCTION,
RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, DISULFIDE BOND, AND GLYCOSYLATION.
RX   PubMed=25282151; DOI=10.1038/nsmb.2900;
RA   Zouridakis M., Giastas P., Zarkadas E., Chroni-Tzartou D.,
RA   Bregestovski P., Tzartos S.J.;
RT   "Crystal structures of free and antagonist-bound states of human
RT   alpha9 nicotinic receptor extracellular domain.";
RL   Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 21:976-980(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Ionotropic receptor with a probable role in the
CC       modulation of auditory stimuli. Agonist binding induces a
CC       conformation change that leads to the opening of an ion-conducting
CC       channel across the plasma membrane (PubMed:11752216,
CC       PubMed:25282151). The channel is permeable to a range of divalent
CC       cations including calcium, the influx of which may activate a
CC       potassium current which hyperpolarizes the cell membrane
CC       (PubMed:11752216, PubMed:25282151). In the ear, this may lead to a
CC       reduction in basilar membrane motion, altering the activity of
CC       auditory nerve fibers and reducing the range of dynamic hearing.
CC       This may protect against acoustic trauma. May also regulate
CC       keratinocyte adhesion (PubMed:11021840).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11021840, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11752216,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:25282151, ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Can form homo- or heterooligomeric channels in
CC       conjunction with CHRNA10 (PubMed:11752216). The native outer hair
CC       cell receptor may be composed of CHRNA9-CHRNA10 heterooligomers.
CC       Interacts with the alpha-conotoxon RgIA (PubMed:22774872).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11752216, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22774872}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P60616:- (xeno); NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-9008641, EBI-16123259;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass membrane protein {ECO:0000305}.
CC       Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25282151}; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein {ECO:0000305|PubMed:25282151}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in cochlea, keratinocytes, pituitary
CC       gland, B-cells and T-cells. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11021840,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11752216, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15531379}.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:25282151}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The heterooligomeric receptor composed of CHRNA9
CC       and CHRNA10 has an atypical pharmacological profile, binding
CC       several non-nicotinic ligands including strychnine (a glycine
CC       receptor antagonist) and atropine (a muscarinic acetylcholine
CC       receptor antagonist). {ECO:0000305|PubMed:11752216}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ion channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family. Acetylcholine receptor (TC 1.A.9.1) subfamily. Alpha-
CC       9/CHRNA9 sub-subfamily. {ECO:0000305}.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.3 ANGSTROMS) OF 470-672 IN COMPLEX WITH CAMP,
RP   NUCLEOTIDE-BINDING, ENZYME REGULATION, AND SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=22006928; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M111.297606;
RA   Lolicato M., Nardini M., Gazzarrini S., Moller S., Bertinetti D.,
RA   Herberg F.W., Bolognesi M., Martin H., Fasolini M., Bertrand J.A.,
RA   Arrigoni C., Thiel G., Moroni A.;

RT   specific cAMP gating in hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-
RT   gated channels.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 286:44811-44820(2011).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Hyperpolarization-activated ion channel exhibiting weak
CC       selectivity for potassium over sodium ions. Contributes to the
CC       native pacemaker currents in heart (If) and in neurons (Ih). Can
CC       also transport ammonium in the distal nephron. Produces a large
CC       instantaneous current. Modulated by intracellular chloride ions
CC       and pH; acidic pH shifts the activation to more negative voltages
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10228147,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10524219}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Activated by cAMP, and at 10-100 times higher
CC       concentrations, also by cGMP. cAMP binding causes a conformation
CC       change that leads to the assembly of an active tetramer and
CC       channel opening. Channel activity is modulated by intracellular
CC       chloride ions and pH; acidic pH shifts the activation to more
CC       negative voltages. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10228147,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:22006928}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The potassium channel is composed of a homo- or
CC       heterotetrameric complex of pore-forming subunits. Heterotetramer
CC       with HCN1. Forms an obligate 4:4 complex with accessory subunit
CC       PEX5L. Interacts with KCNE2 (By similarity). Homotetramer.
CC       {ECO:0000250, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22006928}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-1751885, EBI-1751885;
CC       Q4ACU6-1:Shank3 (xeno); NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-1751885, EBI-16201983;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10228147,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10524219}; Multi-pass membrane protein
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10228147, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10524219}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed throughout the brain.
CC       Detected at low levels in heart. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10228147,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9630217}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation at Ser-668 by PRKG2 shifts the voltage-
CC       dependence to more negative voltages, hence counteracting the
CC       stimulatory effect of cGMP on gating. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Inhibited by extracellular cesium ions.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel HCN family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [4] {ECO:0000305}
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=27161501; DOI=10.1016/j.cub.2016.03.049;
RA   Enjin A., Zaharieva E.E., Frank D.D., Mansourian S., Suh G.S.,
RA   Gallio M., Stensmyr M.C.;
RT   "Humidity Sensing in Drosophila.";
RL   Curr. Biol. 26:1352-1358(2016).
RN   [5] {ECO:0000305}
RP   FUNCTION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=27656904; DOI=10.7554/eLife.17879;
RA   Knecht Z.A., Silbering A.F., Ni L., Klein M., Budelli G., Bell R.,
RA   Abuin L., Ferrer A.J., Samuel A.D., Benton R., Garrity P.A.;
RT   "Distinct combinations of variant ionotropic glutamate receptors
RT   mediate thermosensation and hygrosensation in Drosophila.";
RL   Elife 5:0-0(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Integral part of a neural sensory system in the antenna
CC       that provides the neural basis for the response to environmental
CC       changes in humidity (hygrosensation) (PubMed:27161501,
CC       PubMed:27656904). Together with Ir25a and Ir93a, mediates the
CC       response of the hygrosensory sacculus neurons to changes in
CC       relative humidity and is required for dry detection behavior
CC       (PubMed:27161501, PubMed:27656904). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27161501,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27656904}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: In the antenna, detected in sacculus neurons
CC       which innervate the first and second chambers (at protein level).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27656904}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Response of sacculus neurons to changes in
CC       humidity is abolished and consequently larvae fail to move towards
CC       their preferred humidity. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27161501,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27656904}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RX   PubMed=12537572; DOI=10.1186/gb-2002-3-12-research0083;
RA   Misra S., Crosby M.A., Mungall C.J., Matthews B.B., Campbell K.S.,
RA   Hradecky P., Huang Y., Kaminker J.S., Millburn G.H., Prochnik S.E.,

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA] OF 232-868 AND 344-868.
RC   STRAIN=Berkeley; TISSUE=Head, and Testis;
RX   PubMed=12537569; DOI=10.1186/gb-2002-3-12-research0080;
RA   Stapleton M., Carlson J.W., Brokstein P., Yu C., Champe M.,
RA   George R.A., Guarin H., Kronmiller B., Pacleb J.M., Park S., Wan K.H.,
RA   Rubin G.M., Celniker S.E.;

RN   [4] {ECO:0000305}
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=27161501; DOI=10.1016/j.cub.2016.03.049;
RA   Enjin A., Zaharieva E.E., Frank D.D., Mansourian S., Suh G.S.,
RA   Gallio M., Stensmyr M.C.;
RT   "Humidity Sensing in Drosophila.";
RL   Curr. Biol. 26:1352-1358(2016).
RN   [5] {ECO:0000305}
RP   FUNCTION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=27656904; DOI=10.7554/eLife.17879;
RA   Knecht Z.A., Silbering A.F., Ni L., Klein M., Budelli G., Bell R.,
RA   Abuin L., Ferrer A.J., Samuel A.D., Benton R., Garrity P.A.;
RT   "Distinct combinations of variant ionotropic glutamate receptors
RT   mediate thermosensation and hygrosensation in Drosophila.";
RL   Elife 5:0-0(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Integral part of various neural sensory systems in the
CC       antenna that provide the neural basis for the response to
CC       environmental changes in temperature (thermosensation) and
CC       humidity (hygrosensation) (PubMed:27161501, PubMed:27656904).
CC       Together with Ir21a and Ir25a, mediates the response of the larval
CC       dorsal organ cool cells, a trio of cool-responsive neurons, to
CC       cooling and is required for cool avoidance behavior
CC       (PubMed:27656904, PubMed:27161501). Together with Ir25a and Ir40a,
CC       mediates the response of the hydrosensory sacculus neurons to
CC       changes in relative humidity, and is required for dry detection
CC       and humidiy preference behavior (PubMed:27656904,
CC       PubMed:27161501). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27161501,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27656904}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: In the antenna, detected in sacculus neurons
CC       which innervate the first and second chambers (at protein level)
CC       (PubMed:27656904). Expressed in multiple cells of the larval
CC       dorsal organ ganglion, including the dorsal organ cool cells where
CC       it is predominately localized to the dendritic bulbs (at protein
CC       level). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27656904}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Impaired response to environmental cues such
CC       as temperature and humidity (PubMed:27161501, PubMed:27656904).
CC       Response of dorsal organ cool cells to changes in temperature is
CC       abolished and consequently larvae fail to avoid cool temperatures
CC       (PubMed:27161501, PubMed:27656904). Response of sacculus neurons
CC       to changes in humidity is abolished and consequently larvae fail
CC       to move towards their preferred humidity (PubMed:27161501,
CC       PubMed:27656904). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27161501,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27656904}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=AAN71127.1; Type=Miscellaneous discrepancy; Note=Intron retention.; Evidence={ECO:0000305};

RP   FUNCTION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=27126188; DOI=10.7554/eLife.13254;
RA   Ni L., Klein M., Svec K.V., Budelli G., Chang E.C., Ferrer A.J.,
RA   Benton R., Samuel A.D., Garrity P.A.;
RT   "The ionotropic receptors IR21a and IR25a mediate cool sensing in
RT   Drosophila.";
RL   Elife 5:0-0(2016).
RN   [5]
RP   FUNCTION, AND DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE.
RX   PubMed=27656904; DOI=10.7554/eLife.17879;
RA   Knecht Z.A., Silbering A.F., Ni L., Klein M., Budelli G., Bell R.,
RA   Abuin L., Ferrer A.J., Samuel A.D., Benton R., Garrity P.A.;
RT   "Distinct combinations of variant ionotropic glutamate receptors
RT   mediate thermosensation and hygrosensation in Drosophila.";
RL   Elife 5:0-0(2016).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Integral part of a neural sensory system in the antenna
CC       that provides the neural basis for the response to environmental
CC       changes in temperature (thermosensation) (PubMed:27126188,
CC       PubMed:27656904). Together with Ir25a and Ir93a, mediates the
CC       response of the dorsal organ cool cells, a trio of cool-responsive
CC       neurons, to cooling and is required for cool avoidance behavior
CC       (PubMed:27126188, PubMed:27656904). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27126188,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27656904}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000305}; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein {ECO:0000255}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed in the dorsal organ cool cells
CC       (PubMed:27126188). In the antenna, expressed in approximately six
CC       neurons in the arista as well as five to ten neurons near the
CC       third chamber of the sacculus (PubMed:19135896).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19135896, ECO:0000269|PubMed:27126188}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Strong disruption of larval thermotaxis when
CC       exposed to a thermal gradient ranging from 13.5 to 21.5 degrees
CC       Celsius with mutants unable to navigate away from cooler
CC       temperatures and toward warmer temperatures (PubMed:27126188).
CC       Reduced response of dorsal organ cool cells to cooling
CC       (PubMed:27126188, PubMed:27656904). No effect on humidity
CC       preference (PubMed:27656904). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:27126188,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:27656904}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the glutamate-gated ion channel (TC
CC       1.A.10.1) family. {ECO:0000305}.

RN   [19]
RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=23671426; DOI=10.1371/journal.pgen.1003510;
RA   Kovacevic I., Orozco J.M., Cram E.J.;
RT   "Filamin and phospholipase C-epsilon are required for calcium
RT   signaling in the Caenorhabditis elegans spermatheca.";
RL   PLoS Genet. 9:E1003510-E1003510(2013).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Receptor for inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate, a second
CC       messenger that regulates intracellular calcium homeostasis
CC       (PubMed:10499793, PubMed:10610772, PubMed:15194811,
CC       PubMed:16186564, PubMed:23671426). Binds in vitro to both inositol
CC       1,4,5-trisphosphate (1,4,5-InsP3) and inositol 2,4,5-trisphosphate
CC       (2,4,5-InsP3) with high affinity and does not discriminate between
CC       the phosphate at 1 or 2 position (PubMed:10610772). Can also bind
CC       inositol 1,3,4,5-tetrakisphosphate (1,3,4,5-InsP4) and inositol
CC       4,5-bisphosphate (4,5-InsP2), but with lower affinity
CC       (PubMed:10610772). Acts as a timekeeper/rhythm generator via
CC       calcium signaling, affecting the defecation cycle and pharyngeal
CC       pumping (PubMed:10499793, PubMed:11553721, PubMed:12062062,
CC       PubMed:11950942, PubMed:15013747, PubMed:15133127,
CC       PubMed:16186564, PubMed:21191812). Affects normal hermaphrodite
CC       and male fertility as a participant in intracellular signaling by
CC       acting downstream of let-23/lin-3 which regulates ovulation,
CC       spermathecal valve dilation and male mating behavior
CC       (PubMed:9491893, PubMed:15194811, PubMed:16267094,
CC       PubMed:15958491). Important for early embryonic development;
CC       controls epidermal cell migration and may also regulate filopodial
CC       protrusive activity during epithelial morphogenesis
CC       (PubMed:11950942, PubMed:15498499, PubMed:18369461). Component of
CC       inositol trisphosphate (IP3)-mediated downstream signaling
CC       pathways that controls amphid sensory neuronal (ASH)-mediated
CC       response to nose touch and benzaldehyde but not other ASH-mediated
CC       responses (PubMed:19730689). {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10499793,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10610772, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11553721,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11950942, ECO:0000269|PubMed:12062062,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15013747, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15133127,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15194811, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15498499,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15958491, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16186564,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:16267094, ECO:0000269|PubMed:18369461,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19730689, ECO:0000269|PubMed:21191812,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:23671426, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9491893}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with myo-1, myo-2, unc-54/myo-4 and nmy-2. Also
CC       interacts with iri-1. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:12062062,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15133127}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Endoplasmic reticulum membrane
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10610772, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15498499}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P11881,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10610772, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15498499}.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative promoter usage, Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=6;
CC       Name=a {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11237590};
CC         IsoId=Q9Y0A1-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC         Note=Produced by alternative promoter usage.
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11237590};
CC       Name=d {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11237590};
CC         IsoId=Q9Y0A1-2; Sequence=VSP_053337;
CC         Note=Produced by alternative promoter usage.
CC         {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11237590};
CC       Name=e {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10610772, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11237590};
CC         IsoId=Q9Y0A1-3; Sequence=VSP_053338, VSP_053339, VSP_053340,
CC                                  VSP_053343, VSP_053344;
CC         Note=Produced by alternative promoter usage and alternative
CC         splicing. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10610772,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:11237590};
CC       Name=f {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10610772, ECO:0000269|PubMed:11237590};
CC         IsoId=Q9Y0A1-4; Sequence=VSP_053338, VSP_053339;
CC         Note=Produced by alternative promoter usage and alternative
CC         splicing. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10610772,
CC         ECO:0000269|PubMed:11237590};
CC       Name=g {ECO:0000305};
CC         IsoId=Q9Y0A1-5; Sequence=VSP_053338, VSP_053339, VSP_053342,
CC                                  VSP_053345;
CC         Note=Produced by alternative promoter usage and alternative
CC         splicing. {ECO:0000305};
CC       Name=h {ECO:0000305};
CC         IsoId=Q9Y0A1-6; Sequence=VSP_053338, VSP_053339, VSP_053341;
CC         Note=Produced by alternative promoter usage and alternative
CC         splicing. {ECO:0000305};
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Isoform a is expressed in the anterior cells
CC       of the pharyngeal terminal bulb, vulva, rectal epithelial cells,
CC       spicule protractor muscles of the proctodeum and male-specific
CC       neuron CP8 or CP9. Isoform d is expressed in the spermatheca,
CC       excretory cell, amphid socket cells, PDA motor neuron, spicule
CC       retractor muscles, gubernaculum retractor muscles, posterior
CC       oblique muscles, diagonal muscles and the vas deferens. Also
CC       expressed in the intestine, pharynx, pharyngeal isthmus,
CC       pharyngeal intestinal valve, somatic gonad, hypodermal cells of
CC       the vulva, uterine sheath cells, tail, head, LUA motor neuron and
CC       the embryonic epidermis (at protein level).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10499793, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10610772,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11237590, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15498499,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15958491}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The receptor contains a calcium channel in its C-terminal
CC       extremity. Its large N-terminal cytoplasmic region has the ligand-
CC       binding site in the N-terminus and modulatory sites in the middle
CC       portion immediately upstream of the channel region.
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:P11881, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10610772,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11950942}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: Disrupted defecation rhythm with reduced
CC       pharyngeal pumping in the presence of food resulting in
CC       constipation. Disrupted reversal/avoidance response to nose touch.
CC       Hermaphrodites display endomitotic oocytes following spermathecal
CC       dilation defect and defective ovulation. Loss of male fertility
CC       due to defects in turning behavior, spicule insertion and sperm
CC       transfer. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11950942,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:15194811, ECO:0000269|PubMed:15958491,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19730689}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the InsP3 receptor family. {ECO:0000255}.

RL   J. Cardiovasc. Electrophysiol. 21:1365-1372(2010).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Hyperpolarization-activated ion channel with very slow
CC       activation and inactivation exhibiting weak selectivity for
CC       potassium over sodium ions. Contributes to the native pacemaker
CC       currents in heart (If) that regulate the rhythm of heart beat. May
CC       contribute to the native pacemaker currents in neurons (Ih). May
CC       mediate responses to sour stimuli. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10228147,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10430953, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16407510,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:19165230, ECO:0000269|PubMed:20829353}.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: Activated by cAMP. cAMP binding causes a
CC       conformation change that leads to the assembly of an active
CC       tetramer and channel opening. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:16407510,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20829353, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22006928}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. The potassium channel is composed of a
CC       homo- or heterotetrameric complex of pore-forming subunits.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:20829353, ECO:0000269|PubMed:22006928}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Self; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-1753521, EBI-1753521;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10228147,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10430953, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16407510}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10228147,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:10430953, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16407510}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in thalamus, testis and in
CC       heart, both in ventricle and atrium. Detected at much lower levels
CC       in amygdala, substantia nigra, cerebellum and hippocampus.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10228147, ECO:0000269|PubMed:10430953}.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The segment S4 is probably the voltage-sensor and is
CC       characterized by a series of positively charged amino acids at
CC       every third position.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Sick sinus syndrome 2 (SSS2) [MIM:163800]: The term 'sick
CC       sinus syndrome' encompasses a variety of conditions caused by
CC       sinus node dysfunction. The most common clinical manifestations
CC       are syncope, presyncope, dizziness, and fatigue. Electrocardiogram
CC       typically shows sinus bradycardia, sinus arrest, and/or sinoatrial
CC       block. Episodes of atrial tachycardias coexisting with sinus
CC       bradycardia ('tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome') are also common
CC       in this disorder. SSS occurs most often in the elderly associated
CC       with underlying heart disease or previous cardiac surgery, but can
CC       also occur in the fetus, infant, or child without heart disease or
CC       other contributing factors. SSS2 onset is in utero or at birth.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:15123648, ECO:0000269|PubMed:16407510,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:20662977, ECO:0000269|PubMed:23103389}.
CC       Note=The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene
CC       represented in this entry.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Brugada syndrome 8 (BRGDA8) [MIM:613123]: A
CC       tachyarrhythmia characterized by right bundle branch block and ST
CC       segment elevation on an electrocardiogram (ECG). It can cause the
CC       ventricles to beat so fast that the blood is prevented from
CC       circulating efficiently in the body. When this situation occurs,
CC       the individual will faint and may die in a few minutes if the
CC       heart is not reset. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:19165230}. Note=The
CC       disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in
CC       this entry.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Inhibited by extracellular cesium ions.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the potassium channel HCN family.
CC       {ECO:0000305}.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Receptor for ATP that acts as a ligand-gated ion
CC       channel. Responsible for ATP-dependent lysis of macrophages
CC       through the formation of membrane pores permeable to large
CC       molecules. Could function in both fast synaptic transmission and
CC       the ATP-mediated lysis of antigen-presenting cells.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Functional P2XRs are organized as homomeric and
CC       heteromeric trimers. Interacts with LAMA3, ITGB2, ACTB, ACTN4,
CC       SVIL, MPP3, HSPA1, HSPCB, HSPA8, PIK230 and PTPRB (By similarity).
CC       Interacts (via C-terminus) with EMP2 (By similarity).
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q99572}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane
CC       {ECO:0000250|UniProtKB:Q99572}; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylation results in its inactivation. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PTM: ADP-ribosylation at Arg-125 is necessary and sufficient to
CC       activate P2RX7 and gate the channel.
CC   -!- PTM: Palmitoylation of several cysteines in the C-terminal
CC       cytoplasmic tail is required for efficient localization to cell
CC       surface. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the P2X receptor family. {ECO:0000305}.
